and in default of Export or Payment of Duty within Six Months, the Commissioners of Customs may sell the same.

Company empowered to enter Goods if not entered by the Owners thereof.

Such Goods not liable to Seizure for Inaccuracy in Entry.

Goods to be detained till Production of Bills of Lading.

12° & 13° VI CTO RLE, Cap. xxxl

General Fast or Thanksgiving), to cause such Goods to be forthwith landed and warehoused in the Presence of the Officers of the Revenue, who are hereby authorized and directed to take a true and particular Account of the Quantity, Quality, and Species thereof; and in case such Goods shall not be duly exported, or the Duties on such Goods shall not be paid and discharged within Six Calendar Months next after such Report as aforesaid, it shall be lawful for the Commissioners of Customs, and they are hereby authorized and empowered, to sell and dispose of such Goods, or any Part thereof, to answer and satisfy the Duties thereon, rendering the Overples, if any, of the Monies arising by such Sale, after Payment of the Freight, and of any Rates, Charges, or Expenses which may be due to the said Company, to the Owner of such Goods, on Demand : Provided always, that if a Price cannot be obtained for such Goods equal to the full Amount of the Duties of Customs payable thereon, and the Charges of the Sale thereof, and Freight, Rates, Charges, or Expenses as aforesaid, then and in such Case all such Goods shall be effectually destroyed, or otherwise be sold and disposed of, in such Manner, and for such Purposes, and under such Rules, Regulations, and Restrictions, as the Commissioners of Her Majesty's Customs shall from Time to Time direct.

XXI. And be it enacted, That whenever the Despatch of Business shall be obstructed by the Neglect or Delay of the Master or Owners of Vessels, or the Owners or Consignees of Cargoes, both or either, in making or passing due Entries for such Cargoes, or some Part or Parts thereof, it shall be lawful for the proper Officer of the said Company to cause a warehousing Entry or Entries to be made for the Inward Cargo, or any Part or Parts of such Inward Cargo, of any Vessel lying within the said Dock, for which an Entry shall not have been made by the Owner thereof, and for which the Customs Order for the Delivery shall not have been lodged with the proper Officer of the Customs within the said Dock, within Forty-eight Hours from the Day on which the Cargo of such Vessel shall have been reported at the Custom House in Sunderland, such Entry to be made according to the Marks, Numbers, Package or Packages, Qualities, Quantities, or Contents of such Cargo, or Part or Parts thereof, as shall be described in the Report of the Cargo of any such Vessel (such Goods being such as by Law may be warehoused), and forthwith to land and warehouse, both or either, as the Case may be, such Goods, and retain the same as a Security for the Payment of the Duties to which they may be subject, and of the Rates and Sums payable thereon to the said Company, together with the Rent and Freight due thereupon.

XXII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That no Goods entered by the said Company or their Officer as aforesaid shall be liable to Seizure or Forfeiture by reason of any Inaccuracy in the Entry thereof, unless it shall appear to the Commissioners of Customs that such Inaccuracy was intentional or occasioned by wilful or culpable Negligence; and it shall be lawful for the said Company to detain any Goods being in the Possession of the said Company so entered as aforesaid, until the Person applying for the Delivery or Transfer

thereof

421

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxi.

thereof shall have lodged with the said Company a Counterpart of the Bill of Lading which shall have been signed for the same at the Port of Loading in Parts beyond the Seas.

XXIII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Directors Company of the said Company or their proper Officer in that Behalf, whenever ^'prevenT they or he shall see Occasion, to forbid and prevent any Vessel lying in Paf, 0fa the said Dock to break Bulk or land any Part of the Cargo thereof Cargo being until the whole of such Cargo shall have been duly entered at the landed until Custom House, and Orders for the landing thereof lodged with the ,^Custom proper Officers of Her Majesty's Customs at the said Dock; and House, every Master or other Person having the Command of any Vessel

who shall break Bulk or land any Part of the Cargo thereof, after Notice from such Officer of the said Company not to do so, shall forfeit and pay for every such Offence any Sum not exceeding Twenty Pounds: Provided always, that nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend to prevent the proper Officer of Her Majesty's Customs from causing or permitting any Part or Parts of such Cargo to be landed and to be housed with the said Company for the Security of the Revenue, or for clearing the Vessel, whenever he or they shall think fit.

XXIV. And whereas inconvenient and unnecessary Delay may Company occur in the discharging or loading of Ships in the said Dock from the m(ag case Inadequacy, Insufficiency, or improper Conduct of the Persons em- empioyPer-ployed for that Purpose by the Owners or other Persons having the sons to dis-Command of such Vessels, and also from the Negligence or Default charge or of the Masters or other Persons having such Command as aforesaid, ,oai1 Ships, to the great Hindrance of the general Business of the said Dock : Be

it enacted, That whenever such Delay shall take place in the discharging or loading of any Vessel within the said Dock, either from the Inadequacy, Insufficiency, or improper Conduct of the Persons employed for that Purpose, or from the Negligence or Default of the Master or other Person having the Command of such Vessel, it shall and may in every such Case be lawful for the said Company, or the proper Officer thereof in that Behalf, to cause to be employed a sufficient Number of fit and proper Persons to discharge or load or assist in discharging or loading the Cargo of such Vessel, and to make a reasonable Charge for the same upon the Owner thereof, to be recovered in the same Form and by the same Remedies as are appointed and given hereby for the Recovery of the Rates payable to the said Company in respect of such Vessel; and every Master or Penalty on other Person having the Command of any Vessel in the said Dock Master for who shall not properly clear the Deck of such Vessel, by stowing "ot Rearing away such Articles as impede the Delivery of the Cargo, upon being Ves^eUf required so to do by such proper Officer as aforesaid, shall for every any Impedi-such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds. ment to tho

Delivery.

XXV. And be it enacted, That the Master of every Vessel which Master of shall or may load or unload in the said Dock, or some Person ap- Vessel, &c. pointed by him or by the Owner of such Vessel for that Purpose, [0 be on shall, during all the Time employed in loading or unloading or Tfi^of discharging such Vessel, remain on board, and superintend, aid, and loading.

Power to Cormiiis-

li?ver Wear*" belonging to or used by the Commissioners of the River Wear for to use the the exclusive Purposes of their Works, to enter the Basin or Dock of Dock free of the Company with such Boat, Barge, or Vessel, and there to ship or charge. unship any Stone, Timber, or other Materials to be used exclusively in or about the Works of the said Commissioners, and also to enter the said Basin or Dock with any such Barge or Vessel as aforesaid in stormy or tempestuous Weather, and there remain during the Prevalence thereof, without being liable in any such Cases to pay to the said Company any Rates, Duties, or Charges in respect thereof; provided the Gates of the Dock can be opened to admit such Barges, Boats, or Vessels without Injury to the said Dock, and without Danger to the Ships and other Vessels therein; and provided also, that nothing herein contained shall authorize or empower the said Commissioners to bring into the Dock, or to load or unload, any Sand, Ballast, Gravel, and French or common Chalk, or Manure, without paying to the Company the Tolls and Charges payable in respect thereof.

Provisions of

XXVII. And be it enacted, That "The Harbours, Docks, and to ten Vict. Piers Clauses Act, 1817," except where the same shall be repugnant c'2'- j to or inconsistent with the Provisions of this Act, shall be incorporated with this with and be construed as forming Part of this Act: Provided always, Act. that nothing in this Act, or in the said Harbours, Docks, and Piers

Clauses Act contained, shall extend or be construed to extend to compel the Company to provide or keep any Life Boat, Mortar, or Rockets until they shall be required so to do by the Lord High Admiral, or the Commissioners for executing the Office of Lord High Admiral, in Writing under the Hand of the Secretary of the Admiralty; and upon such Requisition being made, the Clauses relating thereto contained in the said Harbours, Docks, and Piers Glauses Act shall as regards this Act be in full Force; and that nothing in this Act, or in the said Harbours, Docks, and Piers Clauses Act contained, shall extend to compel the Company to erect or keep any Match-house, Boat-house, Hut, or Weighing Materials for the Use of the Officers of the Revenue, until the Company shall be required so to do by the Commissioners of Her Majesty's Customs, in Writing; and upon any such Requisition being made, the Clauses relating thereto contained in the said Harbours, Docks, and Piers Clauses Act shall as regards this Act be in full Force.

XXVIII. And whereas Doubts may arise as to the Limits within 10 & 11 Vict, which the Provisions of the said Act of the Eleventh George the (Listin'*9'0 fourth prohibit the casting of Ballast and other Substances, it is Ballast re- expedient that further and more effectual Provisions should be

pealed. made for preventing the casting of Ballast or any other Substances

assist in such loading, unloading, or discharging; and every such Master or Person so appointed as aforesaid who shall neglect or refuse to superintend, aid, and assist in the loading, unloading, and discharging of the same as aforesaid, shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds.

XXVI. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Master nr nflinr Pnrsnn linvinor Charffe of any Boat. Bartre. or Other Vessel

12° & 13° VICTORIA, O/p.xxxi.

within the Limits herein-after defined: Be it therefore enacted, That such Part of the said last-mentioned Act as imposes a Penalty upon Persons casting or unloading Ballast or other Substances within the Limits therein specified shall be and the same is hereby repealed.

XXIX. And be it enacted, That from and after the Expiration of Penalty on Six Calendar Months from the Day on which the Dock or any Part ^™°ns thereof shall be opened for the Reception of Vessels, if the said Com- Uaiiasa into pany or the said Commissioners, or any other Person whomsoever, the ltiver under any Pretence whatever, shall cast or unload any Ballast, Sand, Wear, &c. Stones, Rubbish, Wreck, Filth, Gravel, Coal, Ashes, or other Substance (except upon Land above the full Sea and Tide Mark, or upon some Quay or Staith situated higher than the Flux of the 'fide,) into the Navigation of the said River Wear, so far as the Place called South Biddick or Biddick Ford, or into the Port or Haven of Sunderland as the same extends from the Promontory or Point called Souter Point, about Two Miles from Sunderland Bar towards the Northeast, and so into the Sea to Ten Fathoms at Low Water, and from thence in a supposed Line till it falls (still in 'fen Fathoms at Low Water) opposite to a certain Place called Ryhope Dean, about Two Miles towards the South; or if the said Company or the said Commissioners, or any other Person, shall, at any Time between the passing of this Act and the Expiration of Six Months from the Day on which the said Dock or any Part thereof shall be opened for the Reception of Vessels as aforesaid, cast or unload any such Ballast or other Material or Thing as aforesaid (except as aforesaid) into the Navigation of the said River Wear so far as the said Place called South Biddick or Biddick Ford, or .into the Port or Haven of Sunderland as the same extends from the said Promontory or Point called Souter Point, and so into the Sea to Five Fathoms at Low Water, and from thence in a supposed Line till it falls (still in Five Fathoms at Low Water) opposite to the said Place called Ryhope Dean; or if the said Company or the said Commissioners, or any other Person, shall at any Time after the passing of this Act dig and remove from and out of one Part of the said River, and cast into another Part thereof, any Soil, Ballast, Sand, Stones, Rubbish, Wreck, Filth, Gravel, Coal,

Ashes, or other Substance, except upon Land above the full Sea and Tide Mark, or upon some Quay or Staith situated higher than the Flux of the Tide, the said Company or the said Commissioners or any other Person committing any such Act as aforesaid shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Ten Pounds for every such Offence, to be recovered in a summary Way, and applied in the same Manner as Penalties are recoverable and are to be applied under the said Act of the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His Majesty King George the Fourth: Provided nevertheless, that nothing herein-before contained shall abridge, lessen, defeat, prevent, obstruct, interfere with, or prejudice any Work authorized to be executed, or any Power,

Bight, or Privilege given to the said Sunderland Dock Company by the said Sunderland Dock Act, One thousand eight hundred and forty-six, or to the said Commissioners of the River Wear by the said recited Act of the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His Majesty King George the Fourth.

If Admiralty order a local Survey, the Expense to be defrayed by the Company.

If Works across tidal Waters are abandoned, Admiralty may remove them at the Expense of the Company.

Expenses of Act.

[Public Act.]

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cajt.xxxi.

XXX. And be it enacted, That if after Working Drawings of the Works by this or the said recited Act authorized shall have been submitted to the Lord High Admiral of the United Kingdom, or to the Commissioners for executing the Office of Lord High Admiral, it shall be deemed expedient by him or them to order a local Survey and Examination of such Works, or of the intended Site thereof, the Company shall defray the Costs of such local Survey and Examination, and the Amount thereof shall be a Debt due to Her Majesty from the Company, and, if not paid upon Demand, may be recovered as a Debt due to the Crown, with the Costs of Suit, or may be recovered with Costs, as a Penalty is or may be recoverable from the Company.

XXXI. And be it enacted, That if any Work to be constructed by the Company in or affecting any tidal Water or navigable River, or if any Portion of the Work which affects any such Water or River or Access thereto, shall be abandoned or suffered to fall into Disuse or Decay by the Company, it shall be lawful for the Lord High Admiral, or the Commissioners for executing the Office of Lord High Admiral, to abate and remove the same or such Part or Parts thereof as he or they may at any Time or Times deem fit and proper, and to restore the Site thereof to its former Condition, at the Cost and Charge of the Company, and the Amount thereof shall be a Debt due from the Company to the Crown, and be recoverable accordingly with Costs of Suit.

XXXII. And be it enacted, That all the Costs, Charges, and Expenses of applying for, obtaining, and passing this Act, or preparatory thereto, shall be paid out of the Funds of the Company in preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

XXXIII. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap.\\\i.

LONDON:

Printed by George Edward Eyre and William Spottiswoode, Printers to the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty. 1849.

ANNO DUODECIMO & DECIMO TERTIO

VICTOR I E REGIKE.

Cajo.xxxii.

An Act for defining the Boundaries of the Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge for Ecclesiastical Purposes, for the Union of the said Parishes for other Purposes, and for better paving, lighting, watching, cleansing, and otherwise regulating and improving the Town of Whittlesey.

[26th June 1849.]

WHEREAS the Boundaries of the respective Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge are intermixed and confused: And whereas it would tend greatly to the Benefit of the Inhabitants of the said Parishes if for the general Administration of the Affairs of the said Parishes other than for Ecclesiastical Purposes the same were united into One Parish: And whereas the Parish of Whittlesey Saint Mary is a Vicarage, with the Parish Church thereto belonging, and John Walbanke Childers Esquire has contracted for the Purchase of the Advowson and Right of Patronage of such Vicarage and Parish Church, and the Reverend Simeon Lloyd Pope is the present Vicar thereof: And whereas the Parish of Whittlesey Saint Andrew is a Vicarage, with the Parish Church thereto [Local.] 5 T belonging,

442 12° & 13° VICTORIAE, Cap. xxxii.

belonging, and is in the Patronage of Your Majesty, and under Twenty Pounds Value in Your Majesty's Books, and the Reverend Edmund Reynolds is the present Vicar thereof: And whereas there is at Coates a consecrated Chapel situated in the Parish of Whittlesey Saint Mary or in the Parish of Whittlesey Saint Andrew, called the Chapel of the Holy Trinity, which was built partly out of Funds placed by Parliament at the Disposal of Your Majesty's Commissioners for building new Churches, and the Reverend Thomas Bedford is the present Minister of such Chapel: And whereas the Churches of the aforesaid Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey, and also the Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates aforesaid, are locally situate in the Diocese of Ely, and are subject to the Jurisdiction of the Bishop of Ely : And whereas it would tend greatly to the spiritual Advantage of the Inhabitants of the respective Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew if a defined pastoral Superintendence was established with respect to such Parishes, and if the respective Parish Boundaries of such Parishes were for Ecclesiastical Purposes settled, and if such Parishes were respectively made for Ecclesiastical Purposes separate and distinct Parishes, and a District for Ecclesiastical Purposes assigned to the said Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates as aforesaid: And whereas in consequence of the Confusion of the Boundaries of the said Two Parishes the Churchwardens, Overseers, and other parochial Officers have for many Years past been appointed by the Inhabitants of the Two Parishes jointly and indiscriminately, and such Officers have acted for and been considered as the parochial Officers of the said Two Parishes jointly and indiscriminately, and have not exercised their respective Functions in the separate Parishes independent of the other Parish : And whereas it is expedient that Powers should be granted for lighting, paving, watching, cleansing draining, regulating and improving the Streets, Highways, public Passages and other Places within the Town of Whittlesey in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge, as hereinafter more particularly defined: And whereas the Objects aforesaid cannot be effected without the Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of St. Mary the same, That from and after the passing of this Act each of the said

Whittlesey Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey drew Whit- s'la'* ^or ever thereafter be a separate and distinct Parish for all tlesey to be Ecclesiastical Purposes, and their present Parish Churches respectively separate and shall be the Churches of each such distinct and separate Parish, and distinct that the Boundaries of the Parish of Saint Mary Whittlesey, including Ecclesiast'T ’*ie district Chapelry to be assigned out of the said Parish of Saint cd Purposes. Mary Whittlesey, as herein-after mentioned, to the Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates in Whittlesey, shall be deemed to be comprised within the Limits next herein-after mentioned, that is to say, proceeding from Oakley Dike North-eastwardly along the Middle of Old Bevill's Leam to Angle Bridge, thence Westward along the Middle of the Watercourse called Whittlesey Dike to Beals otherwise Haynes Bridge in the Town of Whittlesey, thence along the Centre of the Town Drain, separating the Premises of Henry Haynes Esquire from

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii.

the Property of the late John Russell, to Paradise Lane, thence along the Centre of Paradise Lane, crossing London Street, along the Middle of Falcon Street, to the Middle of Alms House Street, thence West-wardly to Broad Street, thence Northwardly to the Centre of Whitmore Street, thence Westwardly to the Middle of Windmill Street, thence Northwardly, down the Centre of Baunce Lane, to the Middle of the public Road, thence Eastwardly to the Middle of the Highway or Street called Delph, thence Northwardly, by the Centre of Delph Dike, to the Dog and Doublet Bridge, including all the District East of the said Boundary and South of Smith's Learn; and the Parish of Saint Andrew Whittlesey shall be deemed to be and comprise all such Parts of the said Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey as are not included within the Limits of the Parish of Saint Mary Whittlesey as above defined.

II. And be it enacted, That the distinct and separate Parish and Endowment Vicarage of Saint Mary Whittlesey as aforesaid shall continue to be °£Sai,nt

a Vicarage, and shall be endowed as at present with the Glebe Lands, Church Rent-charges on Land, Monies, and Dividends on the Government Whittlesey. Securities specified in the First Schedule to this Act annexed, in addition to any other Endowments thereto bolonging, and in addition to the surplus Fees, Dues, Easter Offerings, and all other Fees whatsoever now payable to the Minister thereof, and also in addition to the Rent-charge on the Small Tithes herein-after authorized to be made or confirmed by the Owner of such Tithes, as an Augmentation of the Endowment of such Vicarage.

III. And be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful (the Statutes Further En-

of Mortmain or any other Law to the contrary notwithstanding) for dowment of the present or any future Owner of the Tithes of Saint Mary Whittlesey Mary_s

as aforesaid, being seised of an Estate of Inheritance in Fee Simple in ltt esey'

such Tithes, or being otherwise enabled to make such Grant, to create,

by Writing under his Hand and Seal, a perpetual Rent-charge on such Tithes in favour of the Vicarage of Saint Mary Whittlesey as aforesaid, or in like Manner to confirm or increase any voluntary or customary Payment herein-before made out of such Tithes in favour of such Vicarage, to the Extent altogether of Seventy Pounds per Annum; and such Rent-charge shall be binding on the Owner of such Tithes, his Heirs and Assigns; and the Vicar for the Time being of such Vicarage shall have the same Remedies for recovering such Rent-charge, or such Part thereof as shall be in arrear, as any other Vicar has by Law for the Recovery of a Rent-charge in arrear; and the Instrument by which such Rent-charge shall have been so created, increased, or confirmed shall be registered in the Registry of the Diocese of Ely, and an examined Copy thereof, to be furnished by the Registrar thereof, shall be admitted in all Courts, civil, ecclesiastical, and criminal, as Evidence of such Rent-charge having been so created, increased, or confirmed.

IV. And be it enacted, That the distinct and separate Parish of Endowment Saint Andrew Whittlesey as aforesaid shall continue to be a Vicarage, of Saint and shall be endowed as at present with the annual Rent-charge in Andrew lieu of Tithes fixed and apportioned under the Act for the Commu- 1U e,ey‘

444 12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii.

tation of Tithes in England and Wales on the Lands set forth or described in an Award under such Act bearing Date on or about the Sixth Day of February One thousand eight hundred and forty-one, and such distinct and separate Parish shall also be endowed as at present with the Glebe Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments specified or mentioned in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed, in addition to any other Endowments belonging to such Vicarage, and in addition to the Surplice Fees, Dues, Easter Offerings, and all other Fees whatsoever now payable to the Vicar of Saint Andrew Whittlesey.

Present V. And be it enacted, That the present Vicar of the Church of

Vicars to be Saint Mary Whittlesey and the present Vicar of Saint Andrew Vicar^oAhe Whittlesey shall continue to be respectively Vicars of the distinct and respective separate Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whit-distinct and tlesey, without any fresh Presentation, Induction, Institution, or other separate Form of Law being had, observed, or required, and they and their Parishes. respective Successors shall be Vicars, and Bodies Politic and Corporate, and capable of taking and holding such Messuages, Lands, Tithes, and Hereditaments as now belong respectively to them, or any Augmentation or other Endowment granted or to be granted to them, as any other Vicar is by Law entitled to do; and such respective Vicars shall be entitled to take, receive, and recover such and the like Fees, Dues, and Easter Offerings as were payable and recoverable to and by the present respective Ministers of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey before the passing of this Act, and shall have the like Remedies for recovering the Tithes, Rent-charges, or other Endowments respectively belonging to them, as by Law appertain to the Recovery of the same by other Incumbents; and such respective Vicars shall be subject as now to the Jurisdiction of the said Bishop of Ely for the Time being, and they and the respective Patrons of such distinct and separate Parishes shall be subject to the like Laws as are now and shall for the Time being be in force in respect to Ecclesiastical Benefices, and to the Presentation, Institution, and Induction thereto, and shall have all such Rights as they now have, save and except as is herein excepted.

Appointment of Churchwardens.

VI. And be it enacted, That Two fit Persons shall be annually appointed respectively Churchwardens for each of the Churches of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey, such Persons residing within such respective distinct and separate Parishes; and the Appointment of Two such Persons respectively shall in each Case take place at the next annual Period of appointing Parish Officers, at a Meeting of Vestry to be summoned and conducted in the usual Manner prescribed by Law, and every subsequent Appointment of such Persons shall in like Manner take place at the usual Period of appointing Parish Officers; and in each such Case One of such Persons shall be chosen by the Vicar for the Time being of each such distinct and separate Parish, or the Minister serving the same in the Absence of such Vicar, and the other by the Parishioners, to be the Churchwardens of each such distinct and separate Parish; and the Two Persons, when so appointed and elected Churchwardens, in each Case shall appear and be admitted according to Law, and shall

do,

445

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii.

do, perform, and execute all lawful Acts, Matters, and Things incident to the Office of Churchwarden; and the Persons so to be appointed and chosen Churchwardens shall continue in their said Office until others shall be appointed and chosen in their Stead; and after the first Appointment and Election of the respective Churchwardens under the Provisions of this Act the former Right or Custom of choosing Churchwardens for the Two united Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew shall cease and determine:

Provided always, that no Churchwarden appointed or chosen by virtue of this Act shall be by virtue of his Office an Overseer of the Poor.

VII. And be it enacted, That each of the Churches of the separate Repairs of Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey shall Churches of be maintained at the Costs and Charges of the Parishioners of such ®nd separate respective Parishes, and all Sums of Money requisite for that Purpose, parjshes. and for defraying the Expenses attending the Performance of Divine Service therein, shall be provided by Rates to be made, raised, and levied within such respective Parishes, and shall be applied to the Repair and Maintenance of such Churches respectively, and the Payment of the Expenses attending the Performance of Divine Service therein; and such Parishioners respectively shall meet in Vestry for such Purposes in all respects as Parishioners generally are by Law entitled to do; and each such Vestry shall, so far as relates to the Ecclesiastical Concerns of the said respective Parishes, have the usual Powers of a Parish Vestry.

VIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Present Act contained shall alter or affect the Patronage or Right of Presen- Nights of tation at present existing to the respective Churches of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey, but such Patronage or churches of Right of Presentation shall belong to, and, when Occasion shall thesedistinct require, may be exercised, as to the separate and distinct Parish of and separate Saint Mary Whittlesey, by the said John Walhanke Childers Esquire, ^'^altered his Heirs and Assigns, or other the Person being the Patron of the or affected Church of Saint Mary Whittlesey, and as to the said distinct and by this Act. separate Parish and Vicarage of Saint Andrew Whittlesey, by Her Majesty, Her Heirs and Successors, in right of the Crown.

IX. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for Her Majesty's churchCom-Commissioners for building new Churches to assign out of the distinct missioned and separate Parish of Saint Mary Whittlesey as aforesaid a District ra^. assl&n Chapelry to the Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates aforesaid, under chapelry to the Provisions of the Church Building Acts, or some or One of them; the Chapel and such District Chapelry, and the said Chapel, and the Minister at Coates, thereof, shall be subject to the same Rules, Regulations, and Provisions as are enacted under the Provisions of the Church Building

Acts respecting District Chapelries, and the Churches and Ministers thereof, except so far as the same are altered by or are inconsistent with the Provisions of this Act.

X. And be it enacted, That for the Purpose of repairing and keep- Provision for ing in repair the Fabric of the said Chapel at Coates, and of providing £Ie!,air oi

[Local.] 5 U for Coafw.8*

440 12° & 13° VICTORIA, Crt^.xxxii.

for the Expenses attending the Performance of Divine Service in such Chapel, the Churchwardens for the Time being of the said distinct and separate Parish of Saint Mary Whittlesey shall be empowered and they are hereby required annually to make, raise, and levy, by means of a Church Rate within the said distinct and separate Parish of Saint Mary Whittlesey, including also the District Chapelry assigned or to be assigned to the said Chapel at Coates, the Sum of Fifteen Pounds as a Provision for the Repairs of and Expenses attending the Performance of Divine Service at the said Chapel at Coates, and to pay over in each and every Year such Sum to the Churchwardens for the Time being of the said Chapel of Coates, to be applied by the said last-mentioned Churchwardens to the necessary Repairs and Payment of such Expenses, who shall account for the same, and pay over any Surplus that may remain to the next succeeding Churchwardens of such District Chapelry, to be by them in like Manner applied and accounted for from Time to Time.

Right of Pa-

XI. And be it enacted, That the Patronage and Right of Presen-tronage as to tation or Nomination to the said Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates, !u Coates6* before and after the Assignment of a District Chapelry thereto,

‘ °a as herein-before mentioned, shall hereafter belong to, and, when Occasion shall require, may be exercised alternately by Her Majesty, Her Heirs and Successors, and by John Walbanke Childers Esquire, his Heirs and Assigns, or other the Person being the Patron of the Church of Saint Mary Whittlesey, and the first Turn or Right of Presentation which shall occur after the passing of this Act shall belong to the said John Walbanke Childers or other Person as aforesaid : Provided that nothing herein contained shall affect or be construed to affect the present Tenure of the Reverend Thomas Bedford as Incumbent or Minister of the said Chapel.

Endowment

XII. And be it enacted, That the Endowment of the said Chapel of Chapel at at Coates, consisting of the Lands, Houses, Rent-charges, and Divi-oates' dends specified in the Third Schedule to this Act annexed, and all Fees assigned by any Order in Council forming the District Chapelry to the Minister of such Chapel, shall be held and received ami enjoyed by the Incumbent of such Chapel for the Time being for his own Use and Benefit, together with any other Augmentation or Endowment which has been or may be granted to such Incumbent.

Union of

XIII. And be it enacted, That from and after the passing of this Parishes. Act the said Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew shall, for all Purposes other than the Ecclesiastical Purposes herein-before set forth and provided, become and be united into One Parish by the Name of the United Parishes of Saint Mary and Saint Andrew Whittlesey in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge, and that all Law's which at the Time of the passing of this Act shall extend or be applicable to Parishes in England in general shall extend and be applicable to the Parish hereby constituted, to the Intent that the said Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew may for all Purposes whatsoever, except as hereinbefore or herein-after otherwise provided, be united into One Parish by the Name above mentioned.

12° & 13° VICTORIAE, Cap. x\xii.

XIV. And be it enacted, That from and after the passing of this Act the Vestry Room of the Church of Saint Mary Whittlesey shall be the Vestry Room of the said Parish called " The United Parishes of Saint Mary and Saint Andrew Whittlesey in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge," for all Purposes other than Ecclesiastical Purposes, as herein-before otherwise provided; and that all Notices of Vestry Meetings for such Purposes other than Ecclesiastical Purposes as aforesaid, and all other Notices relating to the parochial Concerns of the said Parish, shall be published in the Churches of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey respectively in the usual Manner prescribed by Law; and that at all Vestry Meetings of the united Parish established by this Act the Vicar of the Church of Saint Mary Whittlesey shall be entitled to act as Chairman, and if he shall not be present or shall decline to act then the Vicar of the Church of Saint Andrew Whittlesey shall be entitled to act as Chairman.

XV. And be it enacted, That the Churchwardens and Overseers, and all other Persons who before the passing of this Act shall have been appointed or who at the Time of' the passing of this Act shall be holding any Office or Employment in either of the aforesaid Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary or Whittlesey Saint Andrew, shall and may hold, enjoy, and execute their respective Offices and Employments in the said Parish called " The United Parishes of Saint Mary and Saint Andrew Whittlesey in the Isle of Ely in the County of Cambridge," until the Time for which such Officers or Persons may have been appointed respectively shall have expired, or until they shall have been removed therefrom by due Course of Law j and the said Overseers and other Persons, except the said Churchwardens, shall be removable in like Manner as they or any or either of them might have been removed by Law if appointed to their respective Offices or Employments after the passing of this Act; and the Churchwardens existing at the Time of the passing of this Act shall have the same Powers, Privileges, and Advantages in the said Parish established by this Act, and shall be subject to the same Liabilities, as if this Act had not been passed; and the said Overseers and other Officers and Persons, except the said Churchwardens, shall have the same Powers, Privileges, and Advantages in the said Parish established by this Act as if they had been respectively appointed after the passing of this Act.

XVI. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Persons who at the Time of the passing of this Act shall be acting in the Offices of Churchwardens, Overseers of the Poor, Surveyors of the Highways, or any other parochial Office, and whether acting for the said Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew separately, or for such Parishes as an united Parish, notwithstanding any Invalidity in the Appointment of such Persons to their respective Offices, and also for the Persons who shall be appointed to any of the aforesaid Offices after the passing of this Act, to collect and levy all Rates or Assessments which shall have been made before the passing of this Act for the Relief of the Poor, or any other parochial Purpose within the said Parishes respectively or either of them, whether such Rates shall have been made for the said Parishes separately or for the said Parishes as an united Parish; and that for the Purpose of obviating

any Difficulty which might arise in the Collection of such last-mentioned Rates or Assessments, on account of the Confusion of the Boundaries of the said Parishes, the said Parishes respectively shall for the Purpose of such Collection be deemed to be comprised within the Limits herein-before laid down for the Definition thereof for the Ecclesiastical Purposes herein-before mentioned.

XVII. And be it enacted, That all Acts, Deeds, Transactions, Matters, and Things made, done, or executed before the passing of this Act, by any Person or Persons acting nominally for the United Parishes of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew in the Offices of Surveyors of the Highways or Overseers of the Poor, or any other parochial Office respectively, shall be as valid and effectual in Law as if the said Parishes had been legally united into One Parish at the Time of such Act, Deed, Transaction, Matter, or Thing.

XVIII. And be it enacted, That the "Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845," shall be incorporated with and form Part of this Act, except as herein-after mentioned.

XIX. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Act, or in the said " Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1S45," shall authorize the Commissioners appointed under this Act to purchase or take any Lands, unless with the Consent of and by Agreement with the Owners, Lessees, or Occupiers thereof.

XX. And be it enacted, That "The Commissioners Clauses Act, 1847," excepting so much thereof as relates to the Election and Rotation of Commissioners; "The Towns Improvement Clauses Act, 1847," excepting so much thereof as relates to Plans of the District within the Limits of the special Act, to naming the Streets and numbering the Houses, to the Prevention of Smoke, to the Construction of Houses for Prevention of Fire, to supplying Buildings with fresh Air, to Lodging Houses and to Slaughter-houses; "The Towns Police Clauses Act, 1847," excepting so much thereof as relates to public Bathing; and " The Gasworks Clauses Act, 1847," except so much thereof as relates to the Supply of Gas, and to the Amount of Profit to be received by the Undertakers, shall (save as they are expressly varied, excepted, or altered by this Act) be incorporated with and form Part of this Act.

XXI. And be it enacted, That in citing this Act in other Acts of Parliament, and in legal Proceedings, it shall be sufficient to use the Expression "The Whittlesey Improvement Act, 1849."

XXII. And be it enacted, That every Male Person of full Age who shall be rated to the Rate made for the Relief of the Poor of the Parish established by this Act in respect of Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments situate within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey as defined by this Act, in the net annual Value of Fifteen Pounds or upwards, or who shall be seised or possessed, or in the Enjoyment of the Rents and Profits, of Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments within such

449

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii.

such Limits of the net annual Value of Thirty Pounds, for an Estate not less than a Life in being for his own Use, shall during the Time that he shall be so rated or seised or possessed, or in such Enjoyment as aforesaid, be a Commissioner under this Act: Provided always, that in estimating the Property in respect of which any Person is rated to the said Rate for the Relief of the Poor, for the Purpose of determining whether or not such Person is qualified to be a Commissioner under this Act, no House or Building which shall be rated to the said Rate for the Relief of the Poor at a less annual Value than Fifteen Pounds shall be taken into consideration.

XXIII. And be it enacted, That if any Person, having qualified under this Act to act as Commissioner, shall fail to act as such in the Execution of this Act for Two Years, such Commissioner shall at the Expiration of such Two Years cease to be a Commissioner for a Period of Two Years from the Time of his having so failed to act, after the Expiration of which Period, upon his again making the Declaration required by this Act, he shall be capable of acting as a Commissioner until he shall disqualify himself by such Failure to act as aforesaid, or become otherwise disqualified under the Provisions of this Act.

XXIV. And be it enacted, That the Commissioners herein-before named, and their Successors, shall be the Commissioners for the Purposes of this Act, and for making and maintaining all Works and Conveniences which they may deem necessary for such Purposes, subject to the Provisions contained in this Act, and in the Acts and Clauses of Acts incorporated herewith, and shall be called " The Whittlesey Improvement Commissioners."

XXV. And be it enacted, That this Act, with respect to lighting, paving, watching, cleansing, draining, regulating, and improving, shall be put in force within and shall comprise the following Limits; (that is to say,) proceeding from the North Side of Long Gravel along the Road in a Northwardly Direction to Priors Piece, thence Westward along the Road to Church Field, thence North-westwardly in a direct Line to the West Corner of the House of Ann Hollis now erecting in Stonald Field, thence Northwardly in a direct Line to and including the Premises of George Benson in the same Field, thence Northeastwardly in a direct Line to and including the Premises now in the Occupation of William Medlock in Delph, then Eastward to and including the Premises called the Whitehouse in Delph aforesaid, thence in a South-eastwardly Direction to the House now in the Occupation of John Goodley in Bassenhally Field, thence in a direct Line Southward and Eastward, crossing the March Road, to the Railway Hotel in Lattersey Field, thence South-westwardly to Ashling’s Bridge, thence along Whittlesey Dyke to the Workshop of James Read Boatwright, thence Westward along the North Side of the Gores and the South Side of Orchards in Briggate to the West Corner of Mr. Jeremiah Ast-ling’s Orchard, and thence North-westwardly to Long Gravel.

XXVI. And be it enacted, That the Commissioners shall and may,

subject to the Provisions of this Act, and of the Acts and Clauses of Acts incorporated herewith, cause to be lighted, paved, watched, legume/.] 5 X lated,

iated, and improved the Streets, Highways, public Passages and other Places within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey aforesaid, and for that Purpose may exercise all the Powers vested in them by this Act, and the Acts and Clauses of Acts incorporated herewith.

XXVII. And be it enacted, That the Commissioners for executing this Act shall hold their First General Meeting at some convenient Place within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey, as defined by this Act, on the Third Tuesday after the passing of this Act, between the Hours of Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon and Four of the Clock in the Afternoon, and proceed to put this Act into execution.

XXVIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Act, or the said "Commissioners Clauses Act, 1847," shall extend to compel the Commissioners to hold monthly Meetings for the Transaction of general Business.

XXIX. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Commissioners to provide Lands and Buildings fit and convenient for the depositing of Stone and other Materials for the Highways, and for such Purposes, and for any other Purposes of this Act, to purchase or hire any Lands, Messuages, or Buildings which shall by the Commissioners be considered necessary, of and from any Person who shall be willing to let or sell the same, or to cause any new Erection or Building to be made upon any Land or Ground which shall be purchased or hired under the Provisions of this Act, or of the Acts or Clauses of Acts incorporated with this Act: Provided always, that the Lands and Buildings so to be purchased shall be situate within the Boundaries of the Parish hereby established, and shall not exceed in Quantity in the whole the Amount of Three Acres.

XXX. And be it enacted, That all Conveyances and Leases of Lands to be purchased or hired by the said Commissioners may be made to Two or more of the said Commissioners, as Trustees for the said Commissioners.

XXXI. And be it enacted, That the said Commissioners shall sell and dispose of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments vested in them by virtue of this Act, and the several Acts and Clauses of Acts incorporated with this Act, which shall not be required for the Purposes ol this Act, within Five Years after the same shall not be required, in the same Manner as superfluous Lands are required to be sold under the said "Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845."

XXXII. And be it enacted, That all Monies which shall come to the Hands of the Commissioners in consequence of the Sale of any Lands under the Provisions of this and the said " Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845," shall be applied and disposed of in paying off any Principal Monies at the Time due and owing on the Credit of the Rate herein-after defined as the Improvement Rate hereby authorized to be made.

XXXIII. And be it enacted, That every new Street, not being a Carriage Road, shall be at least Ten Feet wide in the narrowest Part thereof.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii. 451

XXXIV. And be it enacted, That all Vaults, Cellars, Sewers, or Vaults and Drains hereafter to be made under any Street or Way within the said ^™n.*itobe Limits of the said Town of Whittlesey shall be kept in substantial rei,a;r-Repair, to the Satisfaction of the Commissioners; and in case any such

Vault, Arch, Cellar, Sewer, or Drain shall at any Time not be in such substantial Repair, it shall be lawful for the Commissioners to put the same into substantial Repair, and to recover the Expenses incurred thereby from the Owner thereof; and such Owner shall forfeit a Sum not exceeding Twenty Shillings for every Day such Vault,

Arch, Sewer, Cellar, or Drain shall continue out of substantial Repair after Notice in Writing shall have been given to him by the Commissioners to repair the same, and a reasonable Time for completing such Repair shall have elapsed after the Service of such Notice.

XXXV. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Com- Commis-missioners, if they shall think fit, at any Time after the passing of this sinners may Act, to contract with the Owner or Owners for the Time being of P"er^has* or the Gasworks situate in Delph in Whittlesey aforesaid for the Pur- W0|Lks/‘'5 chase of such Gasworks, and to provide such other Gasworks as they shall think necessary, either by the Purchase of any existing Gasworks for the Time being, or by erecting any Gasworks upon any Land which may be purchased or hired by the said Commissioners under the Powers of this Act.

XXXVI. And in order to raise Money for the Purpose of defraying Commis-the Expenses of applying for and obtaining this Act, be it enacted, sioners may That it shall be lawful for the said Commissioners to make One equal 'Il,ney Rate or Assessment upon the Occupiers or Holders of rateable Pro- 0°rA*penses perty within the Limits of the Parish established by this Act, including

Lands used as Arable, Meadow, or Pasture Ground, or as Woodlands, or Market Gardens or Nursery Grounds, according to the annual rateable Value of the same, to be called the " Whittlesey Improvement Act Expenses Rate," and the Money received by the said Commissioners by virtue of such Rate or Assessment shall be applied by them in defraying the Expenses of obtaining this Act: Provided always, that the said Occupiers shall be entitled to deduct One Half Part of the Monies paid by them in respect of such Rate out of the next or any subsequent Payment to their respective Landlords of the Rent payable by them as such Occupiers.

XXXVII. And in order to raise Money for the Purposes of carrying Commis-the Provisions of this Act and of the Acts and Clauses of Acts incor- sioners to porated with this Act into execution, be it enacted, That it shall be Iuake IiatfcS-lawful for the Commissioners, once in every Year, or oftener if they shall think it necessary so to do, to make One or more equal Rate or Rates, Assessment or Assessments, upon the Occupiers or Holders of rateable Property within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey as defined by this Act, according to the annual rateable Value of the same, to be called " The Whittlesey Improvement Rate," so as such Rates or Assessments do not exceed in any Year the Sum of Three Shillings and Sixpence in the Pound on such annual rateable Value:

Provided always, that it shall not be necessary for the Commissioners to make any Sewer Rate distinct from the said Improvement Rate.

XXXVIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That every Person occupying Lands used as Arable and Meadow or Pasture Ground only, or as Woodlands, or Market Gardens or Nursery Grounds, shall be rated in respect of the same in the Proportion of One Fifth Part only of the net annual Value thereof.

XXXIX. Provided always, and be it enacted, That if it shall at any Time appear that the said Sum of Three Shillings and Sixpence in the Pound is not sufficient for the Purposes for which the Improvement Rate is authorized to be levied, it shall be lawful for the Commissioners, with the Consent of the Majority of the Rate-payers assembled at the annual Meeting, to increase the said Rate for the current Year so as the same do not in any One Year exceed the Sum of Five Shillings in the Pound on such rateable Value as aforesaid: Provided always, that Notice of the Intention of the Commissioners to make any such Increase shall be given by them One Month previous to such annual Meeting, by Placards posted in some public Places, ot on or near to the Doors of all Places of Public Worship, within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey as defined by this Act.

XL. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for any Two Justices in Petty Sessions assembled, with the Consent in Writing of the Commissioners, to reduce, remit, or give Time for the Payment of any Rate, on account of the Poverty or Sickness of any Person liable to the Payment of the Rate.

XLI. And be it enacted, That the Owners of all rateable Property within the said Limits of the Town of Whittlesey the yearly Rent or Value whereof respectively shall not exceed Five Pounds, or which shall be let to weekly or monthly Tenants, or in separate Apartments shall be rated to and pay the Rates by this Act directed to be made, instead of the Occupiers thereof.

XLII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Commissioners from Time to Time to borrow at Interest on the Credit of the said Whittlesey Improvement Rate herein-before authorized to be made and levied, of and from any Person who shall be willing to advance the same, any Sum or Sums of Money which, together with any Sum previously borrowed on the Credit of the same Rate, shall not exceed the Sum of Ten thousand Pounds, and in the event of all or any Part of such Money being repaid by the Commissioners to reborrow the same, and so toties quo ties, but so nevertheless that there shall not be owing on the Security of the said Rate any more than the Sum of Ten thousand Pounds in the whole at any One Time; and for securing the Repayment of the Monies so to be borrowed, with Interest at a Rate not exceeding Five Pounds per Centum per Annum, the Commissioners may mortgage and assign over the said Improvement Rate or any Part thereof to the Person who shall advance or lend such Money, or his Trustee, as a Security for the Payment of the Money so to be borrowed, together with Interest for the same.

XLIII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for any Mortgagee or Mortgagees of the Commissioners to enforce the Payment ot

the

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xxxii. 453

the Arrears of Principal and Interest due on any such Mortgage by the Appointment of a Receiver; and in order to authorize the Appointment of such Receiver in the event of the Principal Monies and Interest due on such Mortgage or Mortgages not being duly paid, the Amount owing to the Mortgagee or Mortgagees by whom the Application for a Receiver shall be made shall not be less than One thousand Pounds in the whole.

XLIV. And be it enacted, That all Monies to arise from the Rates Application to be raised and levied under the Name " The Whittlesey Improve- of Monies, ment Rate," and all Money to be raised on the Credit of the same,

and all other Money which may come into the Hands of the Commissioners in carrying the Provisions of this Act into execution, excepting the Monies to be raised by means of the said Whittlesey Improvement Act Expenses Rate, shall be applied in carrying the several Provisions of this Act into execution, as the Commissioners shall order and determine.

XLV. And be it enacted, That nothing in this Act, or in any Act As to Service

incorporated herewith, shall make Service of any Writ or Proceeding of "nls-

at Law or in Equity a good Service by the same being transmitted through the Post Office.

XLVI. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing herein Saving contained shall extend or be construed to extend in any Manner to Rights of alter or affect the Tenure or Trusts of any Estates belonging to the Clmrcl'Pr0‘ Churches of Saint Mary Whittlesey or Saint Andrew Whittlesey, or ,>erl-' either of such Churches, or to the Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates in Whittlesey aforesaid, except so far as such Tenures or Trusts are altered or affected by this Act.

XLVII. And be it enacted, That all Orders, Rules, and Regu- Confirming lations heretofore issued by the Poor Law Commissioners to the °rtlers of Churchwardens and Overseers of the United Parishes of Saint Mary g""dLa'v and Saint Andrew Whittlesey, or to the Board of Guardians of such United Parishes, shall, if otherwise lawful, be and be deemed to have been valid for all Purposes, although the said Parishes were not in Law united, whether such Parishes shall have been described in such Orders, Rules, or Regulations as a Union, or as a Parish, or as United Parishes.

XLVIII. Saving always to the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, Saving as to Her Heirs and Successors, and all other Persons, Bodies Politic and Patronage of Corporate, and their Heirs, Successors, Executors, and Administrators Sl- MarJ% respectively, save and except the Right Reverend Thomas Lord Bishop of Ely and his Successors, the said John Walbanke Childers, his Heirs and Assigns, and the said Simeon Lloyd Pope and his Successors, Vicars of Saint Mary Whittlesey aforesaid, all such Estate,

Right, Title, Claim, and Demand of, in, to, or out of the Advowson and Right of Patronage of the Vicarage of Saint Mary Whittlesey, and all and singular the Tithes, Tithe Rents, Glebe Lands, Endowments, Rent-charges, and Emoluments of the said Vicarage, as they or any of them had before the passing of this Act, or could or might [Local.'] 5 Y have

454 12° & 13° VICTORIA, CV/;;.xxxii.

have held or enjoyed in case this Act had not been passed : Provided always, that the Saving hereby made shall not extend so as in any way to interfere with or disturb the Settlement of the Boundaries of the said Parishes of Saint Mary Whittlesey and Saint Andrew Whittlesey respectively as defined and established for Ecclesiastical Purposes by this Act.

XLIX. And be it enacted, That nothing herein contained shall extend to, or be deemed, construed, or taken as in anywise extending to extinguish, prejudice, or affect any Rights, Privilege, or Franchise now belonging to any Lord of a Manor in respect of any Market or Fair usually' holden within the Limits of the Town of Whittlesey as defined by this Act, but that all such Rights, Privileges, and Franchises respectively shall remain, continue, and be used, exercised, and enjoyed in the same Manner in all respects as if this Act had not been made.

Undertaking L. And be it enacted, That nothing herein contained shall be not to be deemed or construed to exempt the said Commissioners or District uTm Vic" fr°nl ^le Provisions of the Public Health Act, 1848, or of any general c. ns. " Act relating thereto or to the Subject Matter thereof which may pass during this present or any future Session of Parliament.

[Public Act.]

LI. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such.

The SCHEDULES to which this Act refers.

The FIRST SCHEDULE.

An Account of the Monies, Glebe Lands, and other Endowments belonging to the Church of Saint Mary Whittlesey; viz.,

An annual Stipend payable by the Owner of the Small Tithes (now J. W. Childers, Esquire), which has been voluntarily increased for the last Forty Years by the Sum of Fifty Pounds, making in the whole Seventy Pounds.

A Parcel of Land in Lattersey Field in Whittlesey aforesaid, containing 27a. 2r. 24p., Part of 28a. 3r. 5p. (more or less), bounded on the North by the Twenty-fifth private Road, on the South by the Benwick Road, on the West by Allotments to John Burnham, John Bellars, and Henry John Bellars respectively, and on the East by Allotments to Thomas Ground and Elizabeth Vokes respectively, now in the Occupation of Charles Boultbee and others, at yearly Rents amounting together to the Sum of Eighty-two Pounds.

N.B.—1a. Ou. 21p., the Remainder of this Land, was sold to the Eastern Counties Railway Company for the Sum of 252/. 10s., which has been invested in Consols.

Eight Acres Two Roods and Twenty-one Perches (more or less) of Land situate in Bassenhally Moor in Whittlesey aforesaid, bounded on the North by Green Drove, on the East by Lands of Henry Clarke, on the South by the Counter Drain, and on the West by Land of John Boyce, in the Occupation of William Dial, at the annual Rent of Twelve Pounds.

Ten Acres and Eight Perches (more or less) of Land, situated at Black Bush in Whittlesey aforesaid, bounded on the North by Lands late belonging to Elizabeth Ground, Widow, on the East by the Mill Drain, on the South by Lands belonging to the Trustees of Farcet School, and on the West by the Long Drove, now in the Occupation of Mr. James Read junior, at the annual Rent of Sixteen Pounds.

Four Acres (more or less) of Land in the Parish of Paston in the County of Northampton, bounded on the North by Carr Dike, on the East by Land now or late of George Holman, and on the South and West by Land of Mr. John Parker, now in the Occupation of Mr. Joseph Preston, at the annual Rent of Eight Pounds.

A yearly Rent-charge of Thirty Shillings for preaching a Sermon on Good Friday, charged on a Piece of Land at Coates by the Will of Mary H utchinson deceased.

An annual Sum of Twenty-eight Pounds Thirteen Shillings and Tour-pence, being the Dividends arising from Eight hundred and fifty Pounds granted by Queen Anne’s Bounty, and Two hundred and nine Pounds from the Parliamentary Grant Fund, which were invested in the Three per Cent. Consols.

The annual Sum of Eight Pounds Six Shillings and Two pence, being the Dividends arising from the Purchase Money of the Land sold to the Eastern Counties Railway Company, which was invested in the Three per Cent. Consols.

The SECOND SCHEDULE.

An Account of the Glebe Land, Tenements, Monies, and other Endowments belonging and appertaining to the Parish Church of Saint Andrew Whittlesey.

The annual Sum of Four hundred and fifty-one Pounds, awarded pursuant to and subject to the Provisions of the Act for the Commutation of Tithes in England and Wales, by way of Rent-charge, to the Vicar of Whittlesey Saint Andrew, and which said Rent-charge is by the Award of John Maurice Herbert, Esquire, One of the Assistant Tithe Commissioners, fixed and apportioned upon the Lands comprised within the following Boundary; (that is to say,)

A Line commencing at the Point where Smith’s Learn enters the Parishes of Whittlesey on the West, and proceeding thence in a North-eastern Direction along the Middle of Smith’s Leam to the Dog and Doublet Bridge, thence Southward along the Middle of the public Highway leading from the Dog and Doublet to the Town of Whittlesey, thence along the Middle of the Highway or Street called Delph to the Street called Gracious Street, thence Westward along the Middle of Gracious Street to the Lane called Baunce Lane, thence Southward along Baunce Lane aforesaid to the Street called Whitmore Street, thence Westward along the Middle of Whitmore Street aforesaid to the Street called Church Street, thence Southward along the Middle of Church Street aforesaid to Briggate Bridge, thence Eastward along the Middle of the Watercourse called Whittlesey Dike to Angle Bridge, thence South-westward along the Middle of Old Bevill’s Leam to Oakley Dike, thence North-westward along the outer Boundary of the District comprising the Two Parishes ol Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew to the said Point where Smith’s Leam enters the said District on the West.

The Glebe consists of a Parcel of Land in Church Field in Whittlesey aforesaid, containing 6a. Ok. Gp. (more or less), bounded on the North by Allotments to Charles Bonltbee, Matthew Dial, William Gibbs, and John Lamb respectively, on the East by the Town Road, on the South by the Thirteenth private Road, and an old Inclosure of Thomas Blunt, and on the West by an Allotment to Ann Lamb,

A Cottage in Church Street, Whittlesey, called the Vicarage House, in the Occupation of John Bellamy, at the annual Rent of Six Pounds.

The Surplice Fees amount annually to about the Sum of Ten Pounds.

The THIRD SCHEDULE.

An Account of the Endowment of the Chapel of the Holy Trinity at Coates in Whittlesey in the Isle of Ely and County of Cambridge.

A Copyhold Messuage, with Outhouses, Yards, Gardens, and Appurtenances, situate and being at Coates aforesaid, purchased by the Governors of the Bounty of Queen Anne, in the Year One thousand eight hundred and forty-four, of the Honourable Selena Childers and John Walbanke Childers, Esquire, out of Monies appropriated to and for the Augmentation of the said Curacy, and by them surrendered to the Use of the Reverend Thomas Bedford and his Successors, Curates of the Curacy of Holy Trinity at Coates aforesaid, for ever, according to the Custom of the Manors of Whittlesey Saint Mary and Whittlesey Saint Andrew, for the perpetual Augmentation of the said Curacy.

The Sum of Seventy Pounds, being a perpetual and fixed annual Rent-charge arising from an Estate in the Parish of Whittlesey aforesaid, belonging to the said Selena Childers and John Walbanke Childers.

The Sum of Twenty Pounds, being also a perpetual and fixed annual Rent-charge, arising from an Estate in the Parish of Whittlesey aforesaid, belonging to Mr. Joseph Waddelow.

The Interest of about Two hundred Pounds, in the Hands of the Treasurer of the Bounty of Queen Anne.

VI(TORI E REGINA.

An Act for extending the Powers of the London and South-western Railway Company for purchasing Lands for and completing the Works of the Railways from Basingstoke to Salisbury and from Farnham to Alton, and for other Purposes.

An Act for making a Railway from London to Southampton, 4 & 5 W. 4. several Persons were incorporated, by the Name of " The London and c-88-Southampton Railway Company," for executing such Undertaking:

And whereas the following Acts relating to such Company, the Name whereof is now " The London and South-western Railway Company," have since been passed; to wit, " The London and South-western Railway Deviations Act, 1837," and "The Portsmouth Branch Railway Act, 1839," and " The London and South-western Railway Company’s Amendment Act, 1841," and "The Salisbury Branch Railway Act, 1844," and " The London and South-western Railway Company’s Amendment Act, 1844," and " The London and South-

Company’s (Widening and York Road Station Enlargement) Act, 1847," and "The Exeter and Exmouth Railway Act, 1847," and " The Sutton Harbour Act, 1847," and " The Southampton and Dorchester Railway (Lyminglon and Eling Branches) Act, 1847," and " The Southampton and Dorchester Railway (Weymouth Branch Act), 1847," ar|d " The London and South-western Railway Company’s [Andover and Southampton Junction) Railway Act, 1847," aid "The London and South-western Rail way Company’s [Portsmouth Extensions and Godalming Deviation) Act, 1817," and " The London and Southwestern Railway Company’s Amendment Act, 1847," and " The London and Soidh-western and Southampton and Dorchester Railways Amalgamation Act, 1848 And whereas by or under and in pursuance of the Provisions of the recited Acts the Company were authorized to raise Capital to the aggregate Amount of Seven millions four hundred and thirty-four thousand and fifty Pounds, and they have at divers Times created Shares to such Amount accordingly: And whereas certain of such Shares, fully paid up, have been converted into transferable Stock : And whereas the Powers of the Company for issuing Shares, and for making Calls on Shares, have not yet been fully exercised : And whereas the Holders of certain of such Shares, fully paid up to the aggregate Amount of Fourteen thousand four hundred Pounds, are entitled to a fixed preferential Dividend thereon of Five Pounds per Centum per Annum, payable out of the Revenue of the Company : And whereas the Holders of such Stock, and of all the other Shares so issued, and not converted into transferable Stock, are entitled to rateable Dividends out of the Revenue of the Company on the Amounts paid up : And whereas such Shares are of various Amounts, and it is expedient to facilitate the Conversion of all such Shares into Shares of like Amount, and the Conversion into transferable Stock of all the Shares fully paid up, and to equalize the Rights and Privileges of the Holders of such Stock and Shares, having due Regard to the Amounts paid up, and the Rights and Privileges of the Shareholders entitled to such fixed preferential Dividend : And whereas by " The London and Southwestern [Farnham and Alton Branch) Act, 1846," the Company were authorized to make the Farnham and Alton Branch Railway, and it was enacted that the Powers of the Company for the compulsory Purchase of Lands for the Purposes of that Act should not be exercised after the Expiration of Three Years from the passing thereof, and that the Railway and Works should be completed within Three Years from the passing thereof, and on the Expiration of such Period the Powers granted to the Company for executing the Railway, or otherwise in relation thereto, should cease to be exercised, except as to so much of the Railway as should then be completed: And whereas by " The London and South-western Railway Company's

Basingstoke

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cup.xxxiii. 463

Basingstoke and Salisbury Extension Act, 1846," the Company were authorized to make the Basingstoke and Salisbury Branch Railway, and it was enacted that the Powers of the Company for the compulsory Purchase of Lands for the Purposes of that Act should not be exercised after the Expiration of Three Years from the passing thereof, and that the Railway and Works should be completed within Five Years from the passing thereof, and on the Expiration of such Period the Powers granted to the Company for executing the Railway, or otherwise in relation thereto, should cease to be exercised, except as to so much of the Railway as should then be completed:

And whereas it is expedient that the Powers of the Company for the Purchase of such Lands and the Completion of such Works should he extended : And whereas, besides certain Acts passed in the last Session of Parliament, the following other Acts relating to the London and South-western Railway Company have been passed; to wit, "The London and South-western Railway Company’s Wandsworth Water Act, 1841," and " The Guildford Junction Railway Act,

1844," and "The Southampton and Dorchester Railway Act, 1845," and "The Richmond Railway Act, 1845," and "The London and South-western Railway Company’s Amendment xYct, 1846," and " The London and South-western Railway Company’s London Bridge Extension Act, 1846," and "The London and South-western (Hampton Court Branch) Act, 1846," and "The London and South western Railway (Cherlsey and Egham Branch) Act, 1846," and "The Exeter and Exmouth Railway Act, 1846," and "The Brighton and Chichester (Portsmouth Extension) and London and South-western Railways Act,

1847:" And whereas the several Purposes herein-before expressed cannot be effected without the Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That in citing this Act for any Purpose whatsoever, it shall Short Title be sufficient to use the Expression "The London and South-western of Act-Extension of Powers Act, 1846."

II. And be it enacted, That this Act, and the several recited Acts, Recited Acts so far as the same respectively are in force, and except so far as the and this Act Provisions thereof respectively are repealed or altered by this Act,

and this Act, shall for the Purposes of this Act be and be carried One Act. into effect as One Act.

thereof as shall then be completed : Provided always, that the Extension of Time for the Purchase of Lands and for the Completion of the Works respectively for the Purposes of the London and Southwestern {Farnham arid Alton Branch) Act, 1846, herein granted, shall not extend to or be exercised by the said Company so as to delay the opening for public Traffic of that Portion of the Line by such Act authorized which is situate between a certain Field in the Parish of W orplesdon, numbered 78 on the Plans referred to in the said last-mentioned Act, and the Guildford Junction Railway, but the said Company shall and they are hereby required forthwith to complete such Portion of the said Line, and to open the same for public Traffic, on or before the Twenty-fourth Day of June One thousand eight hundred and forty-nine, so that the Traffic of the Reading, Guildford, and Reigate Railway Company, requiring to pass over the same Portion of Line, in exercise of the Powers in that Behalf reserved to the same Company by the said Act, may be in no respect impeded or delayed.

IV. Provided always, and be it enacted, That the Justices, Arbitrators, Umpires, or Juries, as the Case may be, who under the Provisions of "The London and South-western Railway (Farnham and Alton Branch) Act, 1846," or of " The London and South-western Railway Company’s Basingstoke and Salisbury Extension Act, 1846," or this Act, shall award or assess the Compensation to be made by the Company to the Owners or Occupiers of or other Persons interested in any of the Lands which the Company are by " The London and South-western Railway (Farnham and Alton Branch) Act, 1846," or by ‘, The London and South-western Railway Company’s Basingstoke and Salisbury Extension Act, 1846," authorized to purchase compulsorily, and which shall be taken or used for the Purposes of the Railways or Works by those Acts or either of them authorized, or which may be injuriously affected by the Construction thereof, shall in estimating the Amount of such Compensation have Regard to anti make Compensation for the additional Damage (if any) sustained by such Owners, Occupiers, or other Persons, by reason of the Extension of Time by this Act granted.
