Interpretation of the Act.

[Public Act.]

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. x 1.

XXXV. And be it enacted, That it shall not be lawful for the Company to insure any Person under the Age of Twelve Years, and that every Insurance Ticket obtained by or on behalf of any such Person shall be utterly void against the Company.

XXXVI. And be it enacted, That no Contract of the Company, or any Compensation received or recoverable by virtue of such Contract either under this Act or otherwise, shall be field to prejudice or affect any Right of Action, Claim, or Demand which any Person, or his Executors or Administrators, may have against any Company or Person for the Injury in respect of which such Compensation shall be received or recoverable, whether the Injury shall have been fatal or otherwise, either at Common Law or under or by virtue of an Act passed in the Ninth and Tenth Years of the Reign of Her present Majesty, intituled An Act for compensating the Families of Persons killed by Accidents, or any other Act of Parliament.

XXXVII. And be it enacted, That all the Costs and Expenses attending the applying for, obtaining, and passing this Act shall be paid out of the Funds of the Company in preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

XXXVIII. And be it enacted, That in this Act the following Words and Expressions shall have the several Meanings hereby assigned to them, unless there be something in the Subject or Context repugnant to such Construction; (that is to say,)

Words importing the Singular Number shall include the Plural Number, and Words importing the Plural Number shall include the Singular Number:

Words importing the Masculine Gender shall include Females:

The Expression " the Company" shall mean the said Railway Passengers Assurance Company.

XXXIX. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such.

l(i° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xl.

SCHEDULE referred to in the foregoing Act.

THE RAILWAY PASSENGERS ASSURANCE COMPANY,

Empowered by an Act passed in the Twelfth and Thirteenth Years of the Reign of Her Majesty Queen Victoria, intituled " An Act to confer certain Powers on the Railway " Passengers Assurance Company."

Know all Men by these Presents, That if any Person above the Age of Twelve Years, about to travel by Railway, shall, on Payment of the Premium of Insurance demanded by the said Company in respect thereof, duly obtain any Insurance Ticket marked with the Marks of the said Company, the said Company hereby agrees, in consideration of the Payment of such Premium as aforesaid, with such Person as follows; (that is to say,) If such Person shall, while travelling by Railway, and while such Ticket is in full Force and Effect, sustain any personal Injury whatever incident to and consequent on Railway Travelling, whether resulting from Accident or Negligence, then the said Company shall pay to such Person, on Proof of such Injury, such Sum not exceeding One thousand Pounds if such Person so injured as aforesaid at the Time of such Injury was a First-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Class, or not exceeding Five hundred Pounds if such Person was a Second-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Second Class, or not exceeding Two hundred Pounds if such Person was a Third-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Third Class, as shall be deemed a reasonable and liberal Compensation for such Injury, as well as for the Pain of Mind and Body and the Loss of Time and Money consequent thereon sustained by such Person, such Compensation to be ascertained and paid in the Manner provided by the said Act; and if such Person shall die from the Effect of such Injury within Three Months after the occurring of the same, then the Company shall pay to the Executors or Administrators of such Person, on Proof of such Death, the Sum of One thousand Pounds if such deceased Person was at the Time of the Injury as aforesaid a First-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Class, the Sum of Five hundred Pounds if such Person was at such Time a Second-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Second Class, and the Sum of Two hundred Pounds if such Person was at such Time a Third-class Passenger, and had paid the Premium fixed by the Company for such Third Class.

Provided always, That in case the said Company shall, before the Death of such Person so injured as aforesaid, have paid any Sum of

Money

5G0

V2° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xl

Money to such Person so injured as aforesaid as and by way of Compensation for such Injury, such Sum of Money so paid as aforesaid may, on the Death of such Person so injured as aforesaid, after such Payment or Payments, and within Three Months after the occurring of the said Injury, be deducted by the said Company from the Sum of Money hereby otherwise agreed to be paid by them in the event of such Death as aforesaid; and provided always, that the said Company shall in no Case be liable to pay to the Holder of any Insurance Ticket, or to his Executor or Administrator, any Sum of Money in respect of any Injury wilfully caused by such Holder. In witness, §c.

LONDON:

Printed by George Edward Eyre and William Spottiswoode, Printers to the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty. 1849.

Cap. xli.

An Act to enable the Chester and Holyhead Railway Company to raise a further Sum of Money, and for other Purposes.

[26th June 1849.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Seventh and Eighth

Years of the Reign of Her present Majesty, intituled An 7 & g vict. Act for making a Railway from Chester to Holyhead, c. 65. whereby certain Persons were incorporated by the Name of the " Chester and Holyhead Railway Company And whereas another Act was passed in the Eighth and Ninth Years of the Reign of Her said Majesty, intituled An Act for completing the Line of the Chester g & 9 Vict. and Holyhead Railway, and for amending the Act relating to the said c. 33. Railway: And whereas another Act was passed in the Tenth and Eleventh Years of the Reign of Her said Majesty, intituled An Act to&iiVict. to enable the Chester and Holyhead Railway Company to extend their c. 238.

Line of Railway to the proposed new Harbour at Holyhead, and to contribute towards the Expense of constructing the said Harbour : And whereas another Act was also passed in the Tenth and Eleventh Years of the Reign of Her said Majesty, intituled An Act to authorize an 10 & 11 Vict. Extension of and the Construction of a Station in connexion with the c. 1*7. Chester and Holyhead Railway at Chester, and for other Purposes:

And whereas another Act was passed in the Eleventh and Twelfth [•Local.] 7 C Years

562

11 & 12 Vict, c. 60.

[Short Title.]

Power to raise additional Money by Creation ofnewShares.

Power to raise Money by Mortgage not exceeding 200,000l.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xYi.

Years of the Ileign of Her said Majesty, intituled An Act to enable the Chester and Holyhead Railway Company to purchase, hire, and use Steam Boats, and for other Purposes : And whereas, for the Purpose of enabling the said Chester and Holyhead Railway Company to complete the Works authorized to be executed by the said recited Acts, it is expedient that the Capital of the said Chester and Holyhead Railway Company authorized to be raised by the Acts above recited should be increased, and that the said Acts should be amended for that Purpose; but the Purposes aforesaid cannot be attained without the Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That in citing this Act in Parliamentary and legal Instruments and Documents it shall be sufficient to use the Expression " The Chester and Holyhead Railway (Increase of Capital) Act, 1849."

II. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Company to raise the Sum of Three hundred and twenty-five thousand Pounds by the Creation of new Shares or Stock, in addition to any Sums which they are already authorized to raise, upon such Terms generally and in such Manner as may be or may have been agreed upon at any General Meeting or Meetings of the Company specially convened for the Purpose; or it shall be lawful for the said Company to raise the said Sum of Three hundred and twenty-five thousand Pounds by the Creation of Shares or Stock bearing a guaranteed Rate of Interest or Dividend not exceeding Ten per Centum, to be paid in preference to and before any Dividend shall be payable upon the general Capital of the Company : Provided always, that any preference or guaranteed Shares to be created under the Powers of this Act shall be postponed to and take effect after the preference or guaranteed Shares already created by the Company : Provided also, that Five Pounds per Share shall be the greatest Amount of any One Call which the Directors of the said Company may make on the Shares or Stock to be created under the Powers of this Act, and that there shall be an Interval of Two Calendar Months at least between the Time fixed for the Payment of One Call and the Time fixed for the Payment of the next succeeding Call: Provided always, that all and every Part of such Sum of Money so to be raised shall be applicable only to the Objects and Purposes by this Act authorized.

III. And whereas under and by virtue of the several Acts hereinbefore recited, and also by the Mold Railway Act, 1847, the said Company were empowered to raise the Sum of Two millions seven hundred and eighty thousand Pounds by the Creation of Shares, and a further Sum of Nine hundred and twenty-six thousand three hundred and thirty-two Pounds upon Mortgage of their Undertaking, which last-mentioned Sum or any Part thereof the said Company were authorized to raise by the Creation of Shares, if they should so think fit: And whereas the said Company, instead of borrowing the whole of the said Sum of Nine hundred and twenty-six thousand three hundred and thirty-two Pounds upon Mortgage as aforesaid, have raised

'j; the

503

12" & 13° VICTORIA, CV.xli.

the Sum of Two hundred thousand Pounds, being Part thereof, by the Creation of Shares: And whereas the total Capital which the said Company have raised and are authorized to raise in Shares amounts to the Sum of Two millions nine hundred and eighty thousand Pounds, and the Sum which the said Company are empowered to raise upon Mortgage amounts to the Sum of Seven hundred and twenty-six thousand three hundred and thirty-two Pounds : Be it therefore enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Company, if they shall so think fit, to borrow on Mortgage such Sum of Money as shall from Time to Time be or shall have been authorized to be borrowed by an Order of any General or Special General Meeting of the said Company, not exceeding in the whole the Sum of Two hundred thousand Pounds, as Part of the Sum of Three hundred and twenty-five thousand Pounds herein-before authorized to be raised by the Creation of Shares or Stock.

IV. And be it enacted, That after the whole of the said Sum of Three hundred and twenty-five thousand Pounds shall have been subscribed or raised by Mortgage, as herein-before provided, and One Half of the Sum by this and the said recited Acts authorized to be raised by Shares shall have been paid up, it shall be lawful for the said Company, subject to the same or the like Provisions as are contained in the said recited Acts with reference to the Monies thereby authorized to be borrowed, to borrow on Mortgage such Sums of Money as shall from Time to Time be authorized to bg borrowed by an Order of any General or Special General Meeting of the said Company, not exceeding in the whole the Sum of One hundred and eight thousand Pounds, in addition to the Sums which they are by the said Acts authorized to borrow: Provided always, that the Sum to be borrowed on Mortgage shall not, together with any other Sum which the said Company may be authorized to raise by Mortgage, exceed One Third of the then existing Share Capital of the said Company : Provided also, that all and every Part of such Sum of Money so to be raised shall be applicable only to the Objects and Purposes by this Act authorized.

V. And be it enacted, That if after having borrowed any Part of the Money by this Act authorized to be borrowed the said Company shall pay off the same, it shall be lawful for them again to borrow the Sum so paid off, or any Part thereof, and so from Time to Time.

VI. Provided always, and be it enacted, That all Mortgages granted by the said Company before the passing of this Act, and which shall be in force at the Time of the passing of this Act, shall during the Continuance thereof have Priority over all Mortgages to be created by virtue of this Act.

Vlf. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Company, if they think fit, to raise the additional Sum so authorized to be borrowed, or any Part thereof, by creating new Shares of the Company, instead of borrowing the same, or, having borrowed the same, it shall be lawful for them to continue at Interest only a Part of the additional Sum, if they so think fit, and to raise the Remainder thereof, or any Part of the Remainder thereof by creating new i-.;. .... Shares

ing.

Companies not to pay Interest on Calls paid up.

Deposits for future Bills not to be paid out of the Company’s Capital.

Certain Provisions in first-recited Act as to providing a Station at Ty-Newydd repealed.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xli.

Shares of the Company in manner aforesaid, but no such Augmentation of Capital shall take place unless by Order of a General Meeting of the Company.

VIII. And be it enacted, That it shall not be lawful for the said Company, out of any Money by this Act or any other Act relating to the said Company authorized to be raised by Calls in respect of Shares or by the Exercise of any Power of borrowing, to pay Interest or Dividend to any Shareholder on the Amount of the Calls made in respect of the Shares held by him in the Capital by this Act authorized to be raised : Provided always, that nothing herein-before contained shall be deemed to prevent the said Company from paying to any Shareholder such Interest on Money advanced by him beyond the Amount of the Calls actually made as shall be in conformity with the Provisions contained in the several Acts relating to the said Company.

IX. And be it enacted, That it shall not be lawful for the said Company, out of any Money by this Act or any other Act relating to the said Company authorized to be raised for the Purposes of such Act or Acts, to pay or deposit any Sum of Money which by any Standing Order of either House of Parliament, now in force or hereafter to be in force, may be required to be deposited in respect of any Application to Parliament for the Purpose of obtaining an Act authorizing the said Company to construct any other Railway, or execute any other Work or Undertaking.

X. And whereas by the first-recited Act it was enacted, that the said Company should make simultaneously with the Railway thereby authorized to be made, and for ever thereafter maintain, a convenient Station on the Line of the said Railway at Ty-Newydd in the Parish of Llangadwaladr in the County of Anglesea, together with all necessary and proper Approaches to the said Station from the nearest Highway or Road, and should maintain a sufficient Establishment of Clerks and Porters or other Servants at such Station, and permit the Public to have free Access thereto for the Purpose of joining or communicating with the Trains stopping at such Station, subject to the same Regulations as were applied to other Stations upon the Line: And whereas the said Station was so required to be made by the said Company at the Instance of Owen John Augustus Fuller Meyrick Esquire, the Owner of considerable Property through or upon which the said Railway has been constructed, and as Part of the Consideration for which he disposed of the Parts of his Estate required by the said Company for the Construction of their said Railway: And whereas the said Company have agreed with the said Owen John Augustus Fuller Meyrick to construct a Station, in lieu of the one so as aforesaid required and agreed to be made at Ty-Newydd, on the Site herein-after described or referred to, and which has been found to be more for the public Convenience, and it is therefore expedient that the said Provision should be repealed : Be it therefore enacted, That the said recited Provision shall be and the same is hereby repealed.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xli. 565

XI. And be it enacted, That the said Company shall make, and For provid-for ever thereafter maintain, a convenient Station, to be called " The inS a Station Bodorgan Station," on the Line of the said Railway, at the Spot now Jhe^dorean occupied by the said Railway formerly Part of Fields or Enclosures station, situate in the said Parish of Llangadwaladr in the said County of Anglesey, and numbered 16, 20, 22, and 23 on the Plans of the said

Railway deposited with the Clerk of the Peace for the said County, or some or one of them, together with all necessary and proper Approaches to the said Station from the public Highway or Road numbered 113 on the said Plans in the Parish of Trefdraeth in the said County, and shall maintain a sufficient Establishment of Clerks and Porters, or other Servants, at such Stations, and permit the Public to have free Access thereto for the Purpose of joining or communicating with the Trains stopping at such Station, subject to the same Regulations as are applicable to other Stations upon the said Railway.

XII. And whereas by the firstly-recited Act it was enacted, that Power to the Number of Directors of the said Company should be Eighteen, ^duce whereof Nine should be appointed by the Directors of the London D"r™bt"sof and Birmingham Railway Company, now the London and Northwestern Railway Company, and the Remainder by the Shareholders

of the Chester and Holyhead Railway Company, and it is expedient that the last-mentioned Company should be empowered to reduce the Number of Directors: Be it therefore enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Company, from Time to Time, by the Vote of any General or Special General Meeting, to reduce the Number of Directors to any Number not less than Twelve; and in case of such Reduction being resolved upon the Number of Directors to be appointed by the London and North-western Railway Company shall be reduced in the same Proportion.

XIII. And whereas an Act was passed in the Second Year of Railway the Reign of Her present Majesty, intituled An Act to provide for the Conveyance of the Mails by Railway; and another Act was to the Pro-passed in the Fourth Year of the Reign of Her said Majesty, visions of intituled An Act for regulating Railways; and another Act was l&2 Vict. passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of Her said Majesty, intituled 3'^.’ vict An Act for the better Regulation of Railways, and for the Conveyance c< 97 of Troops; and another Act was passed in the Eighth Year of the 5 & 6 Vict. Reign of Her said Majesty, intituled An Act to attach certain Con- c- 55., ditions to the Construction of future Railways authorized or to be ‘c g.s ^t-authorized by any Act of ' the present or succeeding Sessions of Par- 9"& i’ovici. liament, and for other Purposes in relation to Railways; and cc. 57.105. Two other Acts were passed in the Tenth Year of the lleign of Her said Majesty, intituled respectively An Act for regulating the Gauge of Railways, and An Act for constituting Commissioners of Railways: Be it enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall be held to exempt the Railway by the said recited Acts authorized, or the said Company, from the Provisions of the said several Acts respectively, but that such Provisions shall be in force in respect of the said Railway and Company so far as the same shall be applicable thereto.

566

Railway not exempt from Provisions of future general Acts.

Expenses of Act.

[Public Act.]

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xli.

XIV. And be it enacted, That nothing herein contained shall be deemed or construed to exempt the Railway by the said recited Acts authorized to be made from the Provisions of any general Act relating to such Acts, or of any general Act relating to Railways, now in force or which may hereafter pass during this or any future Session of Parliament, or from any future Revision and Alteration, under the Authority of Parliament, of the maximum Rates of Fares and Charges authorized by the said recited Acts.

XV. And be it enacted, That all the Costs, Charges, and Expenses of obtaining and passing this Act, or incident thereto, shall be paid and defrayed by the said Company out of the Funds of the said Company already raised or received, or to be raised or received by virtue of the said recited Acts or this Act.

XVI. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such.

LONDON:

Printed by George Edward Eyre and William Spottiswoode, Printers to the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty. 1849.

ANNO DUODECIMO & DECIMO TERTIO

VICTORIA REGINAE.

Cap. xlii.

An Act for making the Parish of Richmond in the County of Surrey a District Vicarage, by dividing the Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond into Two separate Vicarages, and for providing a Stipend and Residence for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, and for extinguishing the Vicarial Tithes in the Parish of Richmond, and for other Purposes relating to such Vicarages.

[26th June 1849.]

WHEREAS by an Act of Parliament made and passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act for dividing the Vicarage of 9 G. 3 c. 65. Kingston-upon-Thames in the County of Surrey, with the several Chapelries or Curacies thereto belonging or thereon dependent, into Two separate Vicarages and Two separate Perpetual Curacies, in such Manner as is therein mentioned, it was enacted, that from and after the next Avoidance of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and of the Chapel or Curacy of Sheen otherwise Richmond in the said County of Surrey, the succeeding Vicar of Kingston-upon-[Loca/.] 7 E, Thames

570

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xln.

Thames aforesaid, and his Successors, should for ever hold and enjoy the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and the said Chapel or Curacy of Sheen otherwise Richmond, together with the Hamlets of Ham and Hook, therein mentioned, as One distinct and independent Vicarage, and that the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, together with the Hamlets of Ham and Hook, should be a separate and distinct Vicarage, by the Name of "The Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond," and should be divided from the rest of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames, and the other Chapelries or Curacies thereto belonging or thereon dependent, and should for ever be held and enjoyed by the Vicars thereof, to be nominated and appointed as therein is mentioned, and that all Messuages, Buildings, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments situate within the several Townships, Villages, or Hamlets of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond should from thenceforth constitute the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, and that the Perpetual Advowson, Right of Presentation and Nomination of Vicars to hold the said Vicarage should be and the same was thereby vested in George Hardinge Esquire, therein named, his Heirs and Assigns: Indenture, And whereas by an Indenture bearing Date the Twenty-sixth Day dated 26th of April One thousand seven hundred and eighty-one, and expressed April 1781. £0 [)e macie between the said George Hardinge and Thomas Pickering, therein described (a Trustee for the said George Hardinge), of the one Part, and the Reverend William Cooke Doctor of Divinity, the then Provost of King's College of Blessed Mary and Saint Nicholas of Cambridge, and the Scholars of the same College, of the other Part, the Advowson of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond was granted and assured unto and to the Use of the said Provost and Scholars, their Successors and Assigns, for ever : And whereas by an Act of Parliament made and passed in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the 25 G. 3. c. 4l. Third, intituled An Act to repeal Part of an Act passed in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty, for the Relief and Employment of the Poor of the Parish of Richmond in the County of Surrey, and other Purposes in the said Act mentioned, and for making new Provisions for the Relief and Employment of the Poor, for the Repairs of the Highways, the paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the Streets and other Places in the Town and Parish of Richmond aforesaid, for the Removal and Prevention of Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments therein, for inclosing certain Commons or Waste Lands within the said Parish for the Use of the Poor, and to enable the Vestrymen of the said Parish to erect a Workhouse thereon, and to purchase Land for a Burial Ground, and also to enable His Majesty to shut up a Lane within the said Parish called " Love-lane," it was enacted, that from and after the Twenty-fourth Day of June One thousand seven hundred and eighty-five certain Persons therein named, and their Successors, w'ho should be elected in such Manner as therein-after is mentioned, together with the Minister and Churchwardens of the said Parish for the Time being, and also such acting Justices for the County of Surrey as for the Time being shall be resident within the said Parish of Richmond, should be constituted and called Vestrymen of the said Parish for the Purposes in the said 7 Act

571

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xlii.

Act mentioned, and that they should stand in the Place of and be invested with all such Rights, Privileges, and Authorities as theretofore belonged to or were used or exercised by the Vestry of the whole Parish; and in the said last-mentioned Act are contained Provisions for the Appointment by the said Vestrymen of a Treasurer and other Officers of the said Parish : And whereas the Reverend Samuel Whitlock Gandy Clerk is the Vicar of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, and the ecclesiastical Duties of the said Parish of Richmond are performed by Curates nominated by the said Vicar: And whereas the Pew Rents of the Parish Church of Richmond aforesaid have been by long Usage paid to and received by the said Vestrymen of the said Parish or their Treasurer for the Time being, and the said Vestrymen have from Time to Time thereout paid a Stipend to the Vicar for the Time being of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, and Salaries and Allowances to the Clerk,

Organist, Collector, Pew-opener, Beadle, Verger, and Ringers of the said Parish of Richmond: And whereas the Boundaries of the said Parish of Richmond are well known and defined, and the said Parish is of large Extent, and contains a Population of upwards of Seven thousand seven hundred Souls: And whereas by an Order of Her Order in Majesty in Council, bearing Date the Twenty-ninth Day of November Council, One thousand eight hundred and thirty-eight, a particular District was assigned to the Chapel called " Saint John’s Chapel," in the said asgjgnj,g ’ Parish of Richmond, under the Provisions of the Sixteenth Section District of of an Act passed in the Fifty-ninth Year of the Reign of His Majesty Saint John, King George the Third, intituled An Act to amend and render ^gdQf3 more effectual an Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, for * 13j._' building and promoting the building of additional Churches in populous Parishes, and such District was thereby ordered to be called " Saint John's District," with the Boundaries therein mentioned; and it was thereby further ordered that Marriages, Baptisms, and Churchings should be solemnized and performed in the said Chapel, and that the Fees arising from Marriages and Churchings should belong to the Minister of the said Chapel, and which Order has been duly inserted in the Gazette : And whereas it would tend to improve the Ecclesiastical Superintendence of the said Parish of Richmond, and would in other respects be of public Utility, if upon the next Avoidance of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise‘Richmond the said Parish of Richmond were created a distinct and separate Vicarage from the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames, and if a suitable Residence were provided for the future Vicars of Richmond: And whereas it is estimated that the Value of the Vicarial Tithes (if any) annually accruing within the said Parish of Richmond amounts to the Sum of Two hundred and seventy-four Pounds, or thereabouts: And whereas Doubts have arisen whether or not any Vicarial Tithes are payable in respect of any Lands within the said Parish; and it is expedient that such Doubts should be put an end to, and that all Vicarial Tithes, Small Tithes,

Easter Dues, Oblations, and Offerings (other than Surplice Fees), and all Rent-charges or Payments in lieu of Small Tithes (if any), arising within the said Parish, should be extinguished, and that a Stipend should be raised and secured for the future Vicars of

Richmond,

572

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xlii.

Richmond, and a Residence provided for such future Vicars as hereinafter mentioned: And whereas it is also expedient that the present Rentals of the respective Pews in the said Parish Church of Richmond should be confirmed, and that a Stipend should be assigned to the future Vicars of Richmond out of the said Pew Rents and other Monies herein-after mentioned, and that Powers should be granted for providing a Residence for the said future Vicars, and for other Purposes, as herein-after mentioned : And whereas the said Provost and Scholars of King's College, Cambridge, aforesaid, as Patrons of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, are desirous that the Purposes aforesaid should be carried into effect, and the Consent of the Lord Bishop of Win-chester (the Bishop of the Diocese) and of the said Parish of Richmond in Vestry assembled has been obtained to the Accomplishment of the aforesaid Purposes; but such beneficial Object cannot be effectually carried into execution without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of Richmond the same, That from and immediately after the next Avoidance of to become a t|le sa;c] Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise vfcarace. Richmond the aforesaid Parish of Richmond shall be and become a n distinct and separate Vicarage, and be called "The Vicarage of Richmond," and the Vicar of the said Vicarage of Richmond shall be incorporated and made a Body Politic and Corporate by the Name of " The Vicar of Richmondand shall have perpetual Succession, and he and his Successors shall receive and take all Surplice Fees and Emoluments for parochial Services in the said Parish, and all Stipends and Sums of Money, under or by virtue of any Deed, Will, or other Instrument, or by Custom, payable to the Minister or officiating Minister of the said Parish for the Time being, and shall have the same Powers from Time to Time to nominate and appoint a Minister to the said Chapel called " Saint John's Chapel," in the Parish of Richmond aforesaid, as the Vicar of Kingston-upon-Thames and Richmond now has, and may also receive, take, and hold to himself and themselves all such Lands, Hereditaments, and Rent-charges as may be granted unto or obtained for him or them, in the same Manner as any other Vicar is by Law entitled to do; and all the public and general Laws, Canons, and Statutes of this Realm now in force concerning Vicarages, Vicars, Parish Churches, and parochial Clergy (except as is otherwise specially provided for by this Act) shall be in full Force and have Effect and Operation in all respects in regard to the said Vicarage and Vicarage Church of Richmond, in like Manner as if the same had been at all Times a distinct and separate Vicarage and Vicarage Church, and the same shall be subject to the like Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction, Visitation, and Control as the Vicarage of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond is now subject.

V. And be it enacted, That after the said Parish of Richmond shall Trusts, &c. have become a distinct Vicarage, in all Cases of charitable Bequests or fortheBene-Gifts, whether in Money, or Money in the Funds, or otherwise, which shall have been made or given to the Parish of Richmond exclusively, Richmond or for the Use and Benefit of the Inhabitants of the Poor of such vested in the Parish exclusively, and in all Trust Deeds and Wills relating to the Vicar of same, in which the said Vicar of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen Richmond"* otherwise Richmond, or the Curate or officiating Minister of Richmond, to vest in is as such Vicar a Visitor or Trustee or One of the Trustees of any the Vicar of such charitable Bequests or Gifts, the Minister of the Ecclesiastical Richmond. that District, and the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid shall be and he is hereby declared to be a Visitor and Trustee of such other of the said charitable Bequests or Gifts as are within the Remainder of the said Parish, in the Room and Stead of such Vicar of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, or Curate or officiating Minister of Richmond, as the Case may be; and it shall be lawftd for such Minister of the said District of Saint John, or the said Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, as the Case may be, to do and execute all such Offices and Trusts as ought to be done and performed by those in whose Stead they are by this Act appointed; and the Person or Persons so ceasing to be Visitor, Trustee or Trustees, as aforesaid, is and are hereby indemnified for and in respect of the Surrender of such Office or Trust as aforesaid, and is and are hereby exonerated from the future Performance of the Matters and Things as to such Trusts directed to be performed and done, any Law, Statute, or Usage, or anything in any Will or Wills, Deed or Deeds, to the contrary notwithstanding.

VI. And be it enacted, That from and immediately after the next Avoidance of the said Vicarage of Kingston-upon- Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond all Vicarial Tithes, Small Tithes, Commutation for Small Tithes, Easter Dues, Oblations, and Offerings (if any), and all Rent-charges or Payments in lieu of Vicarial or Small Tithes (if any), arising within the said Parish of Richmond, (other than the Rents and Payments authorized by this Act,) shall cease and be extinguished for ever.

VII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Samuel Whitlock Gandy, at any Time before the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage, to agree with the said Vestrymen of Richmond aforesaid (if they shall be willing) to accept and take an annual or other Stipend out of the said Pew Rents or otherwise, in lieu and Extinguishment of the Vicarial and Small Tithes arising in the said Parish of Richmond, or Commutation for such Tithes; and upon a Deed to that Effect being duly executed, or an Agreement in Writing being signed by the said Samuel Whitlock Gandy, and by any Five or more of the said Vestrymen, and enrolled in the Court of Chancery, or registered in the Registry of the Diocese for the Parts of Surrey, the said Vicarial and Small Tithes, and Commutation, if any, for the same, shall thenceforth become extinguished; and the said Vestrymen are hereby authorized and empowered to enter into any such Arrangement or Agreement for the Extinguishment of the Vicarial and Small Tithes, and Commutation for the same, and to execute and sign any Deed or Agreement for carrying such Extinguishment into effect.

VIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing herein contained shall affect or extinguish, or be construed to affect or extinguish, the Payment of such Fees as are usually known as or called Surplice Fees, which said Surplice Fees (except the Fees for Marriages and Churchings in Saint John’s Chapel aforesaid) shall remain payable to and be recovered and received by the said Samuel Whitlock Gandy so long as he shall remain Vicar of Kingston-upon-

Thames

575

12° & 13° VICTORIAE, Cap.*lii.

Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, and afterwards by the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid for the Time being, in the same Manner as before the passing of this Act the same have or might have been received and recovered by the said Samuel Whitlock Gandy and his Predecessors, Vicars of Kingston-upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond, nor shall the same affect or extinguish or be construed to affect or extinguish the Payment of such Fees for Graves, Vaults, Monuments, Tablets, and Burials in the Church, Churchyard, and Burial Ground of the said Parish of Richmond as have heretofore been accustomed, nor the Rents for Pews, or Seats in Pews, in the Parish Church of Richmond aforesaid, nor any Stipend or Payment that now is or hereafter may be or become payable by virtue of any Will or Gift by Deed made or executed according to Law.

IX. And be it enacted, That the Pew which before the passing of Pew to be this Act shall have been set apart for or occupied by the Curate or s*‘ ?Part for officiating Minister of the said Parish Church of Richmond for the FamTiv'1 Time being, and his Family, shall remain set apart for and be occupied and for

by such Curate or officiating Minister and his Family until some Churchwar-Person shall under this Act become Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, and thenceforward shall be set apart for and occupied by such Vicar " Cl and his Family, and such Pew shall be exempted from the Payment of Rent; and any Pew or Pews which at the Time of the passing of this Act shall have been appropriated, and exempt from Rent, to the Use of the Churchwardens or other Officers of the said Parish, and the Organist and Children of the Parochial School, shall henceforth remain so appropriated and exempt from Rent.

X. And be it enacted, That the Vestrymen of the said Parish of Pew Items to Richmond for the Time being, constituted and appointed pursuant to 1)0 charged the said herein-before in part recited Act of Parliament of the Twenty- ^prepared'0 fifth Year of the Reign of His Majesty King George the Third, i.^t, which herein after called " the Vestrymen," shall cause a List or Schedule shall be

to be made of all the Pews and Seats in Pews in the said Church, fejustered and a Plan of such Pews, and of the respective yearly Rents which on ofores^ the Feast Day of the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary next before the passing of this Act were charged upon or payable by Occupiers of the said Pews and Seats in Pews respectively; and the said Pews and Seats respectively shall from and after the passing of this Act be for ever charged and chargeable with the said respective yearly Rents appearing in the said List or Schedule, subject nevertheless to the Powers and Authorities herein contained for varying the respective Amounts of such Rents; and the said List or Schedule shall be signed by the said Vestrymen or their Chairman for the Time being, and shall be submitted to the Bishop of the Diocese for his Approval, and on his approving the same shall be registered in the Registry of the Diocese lor the Parts of Surrey, within Three Calendar Months after the passing of this Act, and so from Time to Time within Three Calendar Months after any Variations in the Amount of any such Pew Rents shall take place.

shall be let.

to Inhabitant Householders of the said Parish of Richmond, and to any other Person or Persons (subject to the Preference herein-after mentioned), for such Time or Times, and at or for such annual or other Rents, and subject to such Rules, Orders, and Regulations, as are herein-after mentioned; and the Rents to be paid for the Use and Occupation of any Pews or Seats in Pews shall be paid half-yearly and in advance, and shall be applied and disposed of for the Purposes of this Act, as herein-after mentioned: Provided always, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the several Parishioners of the said Parish of Richmond, and Residents therein, on Demand in Writing made to the Churchwardens, or any or either of them, to have or rent such Pews or Seats respectively, at such Rent or Rents, Sum or Sums of Money, as aforesaid, in preference to any other Person or Persons not being a Parishioner or Parishioners of or resident within the said Parish : Provided also, that no Pew or Seat in Pew shall be let to any Person or Persons, not an Inhabitant Householder or Inhabitant Householders of or resident in the said Parish, for any longer Term or Period than One Year: Provided also, that if any such Householder or Householders shall take any such Pew or Seat for any longer Term or Period than One Year, and shall cease to be an Inhabitant Householder or Inhabitant Householders of the said Parish, then and in every such Case his, her, or their Term, Estate, and Interest in such Pew or Seat respectively shall, at the End or Expiration of the then current Year of the said Term or Period, cease and determine to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever.

XIII. And be it enacted, That in case any additional Pew or Pews, or Pews shall be made in the said Parish Church, or any of the exist-Pews^to I 'nS ^>ews therein shall at any Time or Times be enlarged, lessened, charo’edwith 01 a^tered, then such additional Pew or Pews, or the other Pews so Kents. enlarged, lessened, or altered, shall be charged with, and the respective Occupiers of such additional, or enlarged, lessened, or altered Pews, or of any Sitting or Sittings therein, shall be liable to pay, such a Rent or Rents for the same as the Vestry of the said Parish of Richmond for the Time being, with the Consent in Writing of the Bishop of the Diocese, under his Hand and Seal, shall think proper; and all the Clauses and Powers relating to the Pews now existing in the said Church, and to the Rents thereof respectively, and to the Application of such Rents, shall be applicable to such additional Pew or Pews, or other Pew and Pews, that may be so enlarged or lessened or altered as aforesaid.

XV. And be it enacted, That in case the said present or any Pews in new future Parish Church of Richmond aforesaid shall be burnt or de- ^tgjbp^is|, stroyed by Fire, or become decayed, or unfit for the Performance of church to be Divine Service therein, and another Church shall be at any Time charged with or Times built or substituted for it, then the Pews and Sittings in Kents.

Pews in every such new Church or substituted Church shall be charged with, and the Owners and Occupiers thereof respectively, or of any Sitting or Sittings therein, shall be liable to pay, such a Kent or Rents for the same as the said Vestry of the said Parish of Richmond for the Time being, with the Consent in Writing of the Bishop of the Diocese under his Hand and Seal, and of the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, shall think fit, and a Copy of the Rental of such Pews and Sittings in Pews shall be entered in the Registry of the Diocese for the Parts of Surrey within Six Calendar Months after such Rental shall have been settled; and all the Clauses, Powers, and Remedies herein contained for receiving, recovering, and enforcing Payment of the Rents of the Pews and Sittings in Pews in the present Parish Church, and to the Application of such Rents, and otherwise relating to such Pews and Sittings in Pews, shall be in like Manner applicable to the Pews and Sittings in Pews, and Rents thereof respectively, in every such new or substituted Church.

XVI. And be it enacted, That every Occupier of a Pew or Seat in Rents to be a Pew in the Parish Church of Richmond aforesaid shall pay to the Pa^1hal^d said Vestrymen or their Treasurer, or to the Collector to be appointed ^advance, by the said Vestrymen as herein-after mentioned, the Rent charged thereon as aforesaid, by equal half-yearly Payments, namely, on the Twenty-fifth Day of March and the Twenty-ninth Day of September

in every Year, and such half-yearly Payments shall be made in

advance; and in case the Rent of any such Pew or Seat, or any Part

thereof, shall happen to be behind and unpaid by the Space of Three

Calendar Months next after the same shall become due or payable,

Inhabitant or Inhabitants of the said Parish of Richmond, or other Person or Persons, subject to the Preference aforesaid, in such Manner

Until the Parish of Richmond shall become a distinct Vicarage, the Pew Rents to be paid and applied as heretofore. No new Vaults to be in the Church.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xlii.

or going out of Office of the said Treasurer or Vestry Clerk, or either of them.

XVII. And be it enacted, That until the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage the said Vestrymen shall pay and apply the said Pew Rents, payable as aforesaid, to the respective Persons and in the Manner and for the Intents and Purposes to whom and in and for which respectively the Pew Rents of the said Church have been before the passing of this Act paid and applied.

XVIII. And be it enacted, That it shall not be lawful to break up the Pavement, or to open the Soil beneath the same, for any new Vault or Grave within the said Church for the Purposes of Burial, or to make any Grave in any Churchyard thereunto adjacent or belonging at any less Distance than Ten Feet from the external Walls of the said Church; provided always, that nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend to prevent the Burial of dead Bodies in any Vault wholly arched with Brick or Stone which may have been constructed for such Purposes under the said Church; and if any Burial shall take place or any Grave be made otherwise than is herein provided, the Person making or ordering or causing the same to be made shall for every such Offence, on Conviction thereof before any Two of Her Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the County of Surrey, forfeit and pay the Sum of Fifty Pounds; and in default of Payment thereof the same shall and may be levied and recovered, by Warrant under the Hands and Seals of such Justices, by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of such Offender, rendering the Overplus, if any, to the Owner thereof; of which Penalty one Moiety shall be given to the Informer, and the other Moiety to the Use of the Poor of the said Parish of Richmond.

XIX. And be it enacted, That from and immediately after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage all Fees for all Graves, Vaults, Monuments, and Burials in the said Church, Churchyard, or Burial Ground of the said Parish, and for all Tablets affixed to the Walls of the said Church or of the Churchyard or Burial Ground, shall be paid to and be received by the Treasurer of the said Parish for the Time being; and the said Treasurer shall, from Time to Time as and when the same shall be received, pay One Moiety or equal Half' Part of the net Proceeds of such Fees to the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid for the Time being, and the remaining Moiety or equal Half Part thereof shall be applied by the said Treasurer for the Purposes herein-after mentioned; and the said Treasurer shall pay over to the said Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, at least twice in every Year, his Portion of such Fees; and the said Treasurer shall, if thereunto required by the saiil Vicar, make out at least once a Year an Account of all such Fees (signed by himself), and deliver the same to the said Vicar of Richmond.

XX. And be it enacted, That from and immediately after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage the said

Vestrymen,

12" & 1.3° VICTORIA, Ciip.xiu.

Vestrymen, by and out of the net Receipts of the said Pew Rents, and by and out of the said remaining Moiety or Half Part of the net Proceeds of such Fees as aforesaid, do and shall, in the first place, pay an annual Stipend or Sum of Four hundred Pounds, by equal half-yearly Payments on the Twenty-fifth Day of March and Twenty-ninth Day of September in every Year, to the said Vicar of the said Parish of Richmond for the Time being, after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage, for his own Use and Benefit, during his Incumbency, the first of such half-yearly Payments to commence on and from the Induction of such Vicar, anti a proportionate Part thereof to become due and payable on such of the said half-yearly Days of Payment as shall next happen after such Induction, and in case of the Determination of the Incumbency of any such Vicar between any of the said half-yearly Days of Payment do and shall pay to the said Incumbent whose Incumbency shall so determine, his Executors or Administrators, a proportionate Part of the said Stipend up to the Time of the Determination of such Incumbency, and do and shall, in the next place, pay the Salaries, Allowances, and Expenses (or some of them) specified in the Schedule to this Act annexed, and do and shall on the Twenty-fifth Day of March in every Year pay the Surplus (if any) to the Vicar of Richmond for the Time being, for his own Use and Benefit, or, in case of the Vicarage being then void, to the Vicar who shall be inducted to the same to fill up such Avoidance.

XXI. And be it enacted, That the said Vestrymen shall and they are hereby required, within the Space of Twelve Calendar Months after the passing of this Act, provided the said Parish of Richmond shall be then a distinct Vicarage, and if not then within the Space of Twelve Calendar Months after it shall have become a distinct Vicarage, to provide or procure for the Vicar of Richmond for the Time being a suitable Residence, of Freehold or Copyhold Tenure, within the said Parish (subject nevertheless to such Residence, if Copyhold, being enfranchised as mentioned or provided for by this Act), and the same shall be conveyed to and vested in the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid and his Successors (or in case there shall not then be any Vicar, then to Trustees, as herein-after provided for), and he and they are hereby empowered to accept and hold the same for ever as Part of the Endowment of such Vicarage, subject to such Power of Sale and Exchange as herein-after contained, and (subject as aforesaid) the same shall thenceforth become and remain subject to all the public and general Laws and Statutes of the Realm concerning the Residences of the Clergy, in like Manner as if the said Vicarage of Richmond had at all Times been a distinct Vicarage, and the said Residence been at all Times the appropriated Residence of the Vicar: Provided always, that in case a suitable Residence, or the Means of procuring or providing a suitable Residence, for the said Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, shall be given or granted by any Trustees, Guardians, Commissioners, or other Persons, or Body Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, pursuant to the Power contained in or given or reserved by tins Act or otherwise, then the Liability by this Act imposed on the said Vestrymen of Richmond of providing or procuring such Residence shall cease and become void and of no Effect;

XXII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen Vestrymen of Richmond, by Deed under the Hands and Seals of the of fh^'psaid Vestrymen or any Five or more of them (upon being after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage, to grant and convey to the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid and his Successors, or to Trustees, as herein-after provided for, as and for a Site for a Residence and a Garden thereto, or for an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond, any Part (not exceeding in Extent One Acre and a Quarter) of any Lands now held by the said Vestrymen under and by virtue of the said herein-before in part recited Act of the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, or the Grant made in pursuance thereof (except any Part of the Land formerly the Hill Common'), and the said Land shall be conveyed to and held by the said Vicar and his Successors (subject to such Power of Sale and Exchange as herein-after contained) freed and discharged from the Trusts and Purposes mentioned in the said Act and Grant or either of them, and the said Vestrymen are hereby empowered to make such Grant and Conveyance without any valuable Consideration, or for a Consideration in Money or otherwise, as they shall think fit: Provided always, that instead of the said Vestrymen granting and conveying any Part of the said Lands as aforesaid as or for a Residence or Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond, it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen, or a Majority of them assembled at a General Meeting, by the Order or Direction of the High Court of Chancery, upon a Petition or Petitions to be presented in a summary Way by the said Vestrymen or any Five or more of them, to be entitled in the Matter of this Act, (the Costs, Charges, and Expenses of which Petition or Petitions, and of all Proceedings under the same, shall be paid out of the Rents and Profits of the said Lands so held by the said Vestrymen, and which Petition and Petitions shall and may be presented at any Time or Times within the Space of Twelve Calendar Months after the passing of this Act, or within Twelve Calendar Months after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage, although there shall not be any Cause in the said Court relating to the said Trust Land or the Matter of such Petition or Petitions, and with which Petition or Petitions, or any Copy thereof, it shall not be necessary to serve the Attorney General or any other Party,) to sell and dispose of any Part not exceeding One Acre and a Quarter of the said Lands (except any Part of the Land formerly the Hitt Common), either by public Auction or private Contract, and by Deed or Deeds under the Hands and Seals of the said Vestrymen or any Five or more of them to convey the Land so sold unto the Purchaser or Purchasers thereof, freed and discharged

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xlii.

discharged from the Trusts and Purposes in the said Act and Grant mentioned; and the Receipt and Receipts of the said Vestrymen, or any Five or more of them, for the Purchase Money of the Land so sold, shall he a sufficient Discharge and Discharges for any such Purchase or Consideration Money, and shall acquit and discharge every Purchaser or Purchasers and every other Person from seeing to the Application thereof, and from being accountable for the Nonapplication or Misapplication thereof; and the Monies to arise from any Sale or Sales as aforesaid, after Payment thereout of the Expenses of such Sale or Sales, shall be paid ami applied by the said Vestrymen in, for, or towards providing or procuring a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, or for an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond.

XXIII. And be it enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Trustees Trustees of for the Time being of the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments Richmond called the Richmond Church Estate, at Richmond aforesaid, by the Estate'nm Order or Direction of the High Court of Chancery, upon a Petition give Money or Petitions to be presented in a summary Way by the said Trustees or Land, or Trustee for the Time being, or the major Part of them, to be entitled in the Matter of this Act, (the Costs, Charges, and Expenses

of which Petition or Petitions, and of all Proceedings under the same, shall, if the Court of Chancery shall so direct, be paid out of the Rents and Profits of the said Richmond Church Estate,) and which Petition and Petitions shall and may be presented at any Time or Times, although there shall not be any Cause in the said Court relating to the said Charity, or the Matter of such Petition or Petitions, by and out of any Monies, or Surplus or Accumulations of Rents, arising or which may have arisen or accumulated from such Estates or otherwise, to give to the said Vestrymen a Sum of Money not exceeding Five hundred Pounds Sterling, in, for, or towards providing or procuring a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, or, by any Grant or Conveyance under the Hands and Seals of the said Trustees for the Time being, to give, grant, and convey any Messuage, Land, Tenement, or Hereditament under their Care, Control, or Management as or for a Residence or Site for a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond, or for an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond; and such Grant or Conveyance may be made without any valuable Consideration whatever; and the said Trustees so giving, granting, or conveying as aforesaid are hereby indemnified for or in respect of any such Gift, Grant, or Conveyance.

XXIV. And be it enacted, That at any Time or Times after any Power to Gift, Grant, Purchase, or Conveyance shall have been made or exe- sell and cuted of any Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, as or ^ands"^ for or towards an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond, or vvjtIl con-’ as or for a Residence or Site for a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond sent, aforesaid, it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen or any Five or

more of them, or any Trustee or Trustees of any such Messuages,

Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, by the Direction of a Majority of the Vestrymen of Richmond aforesaid, at One of their Meetings (before the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage), and with the Consent in Writing of the Bishop of the Diocese, testified under his Hand and Seal, and of the Provost and \_Loca!.~\ 7 H Scholars

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xYn.

Scholars of King's College aforesaid, testified under the Seal of the said College, and (after the said Parish of Richmond, shall have become a distinct Vicarage) then it shall be lawful for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid for the Time being, with the like Consent of the said Bishop and Provost and Scholars, testified as aforesaid, at any Time or Times and from Time to Time to dispose of and convey, either by way of absolute Sale or in Exchange, all or any Part of such Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, for any other Endowment or Residence, or Site for a Residence, in the Parish of Richmond aforesaid, either for such a Price or Prices in Money, or for such an Equivalent or Recompence in Lands or Hereditaments, as to the said Vestrymen, and Provost and Scholars, (before the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage,) or, after it shall have become a distinct Vicarage, as to the Vicar of Richmond and the said Provost and Scholars, shall seem fit and reasonable; and that for the Purpose of effectuating such Sale, Exchange, Disposition, or Conveyance it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen, or any Five or more of them, or any Trustee or Trustees of any such Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, (before the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage,) with the Consent in Writing of the Bishop of the Diocese and of the said Provost and Scholars, to be testified as aforesaid, and for the Vicar of Richmond, after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage, (with such Consent as aforesaid, testified as aforesaid,) by any Deed or Deeds, Instrument or Instruments in Writing, absolutely to revoke and determine and make void all and every or any of the Uses, Trusts, Powers, and Provisoes that may be contained or referred to in any Deed or Conveyance of such Lands and Hereditaments, or Residence or Site for a Residence for the said Vicar of Richmond, and by the same or any other Deed or Deeds, Instrument or Instruments in Writing, to limit and declare, direct or appoint, any Use or Uses, Estate or Estates, Trust or Trusts of the said Hereditaments and Premises, which it shall be thought necessary or expedient to limit, declare, direct, or appoint, in order to effectuate such Sale, Exchange, Disposition, or Conveyance as aforesaid, and also that upon any such Exchange as aforesaid it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen or Vicar (as the Case may be) to give or receive any Sum or Sums of Money by way of Equality of Exchange j and also that upon Payment of the Money arising by any Sale of the said Hereditaments and Premises, or any Part thereof, or to be received for Equality of Exchange, as aforesaid, or any Part thereof, it shall be lawful for the said Vestrymen, or any Five or more of them, or any such Trustee or Trustees as aforesaid, (before the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage,) and for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid (after the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage), to sign and give Receipts for the same, and that such Receipts shall be sufficient Discharges to the Person or Persons to whom the same shall be given for the Money therein acknowledged or expressed to be received; and that such Person or Persons, his, her, or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, shall not afterwards be answerable for any Loss, Misapplication, or Nonapplication of such Money, or be obliged or concerned to see to the Application thereof.

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cap. xlii.

XXV. And be it enacted, That when all or any Part of the Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments that may be purchased, given, granted, or acquired as or for an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond, or as or for a Residence or Site for a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, shall be so sold, or any Money shall be so received for Equality of Exchange as aforesaid, all and every the Sum and Sums of Money to arise by such Sale or Sales, or to be received for Equality of Exchange, as aforesaid, or Part thereof, shall with all convenient Speed be laid out and applied in the Purchase of another Residence or Site for a Residence for the Vicar of Richmond aforesaid; and if there shall be any Surplus of such Monies, or if such Monies shall not be required to purchase a Residence or Site for a Residence for the said Vicar, the same shall be laid out in the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or in any of the Public Stocks or Funds of Great Britain, or upon Government or Real Securities in England, and such Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, Stocks, Funds, and Securities, shall thereafter be an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond aforesaid, and the same shall be subject to the like Powers of Sale and Exchange, and Application, as contained in this Act respecting any Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments.

XXVI. And be it enacted, That if any Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments for a Residence or Site for a Residence, or for an Endowment of the Vicarage of Richmond aforesaid, shall be purchased, given, granted, or acquired before there shall be any Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, then and in such Case the Conveyance of such Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments may be made to the Treasurer of the said Parish of Richmond and his Heirs, or to such Two or more Persons, and their Heirs, as the said Vestrymen shall appoint as Trustees, upon trust, when and as soon as there shall be a Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, to convey the same to such Vicar and his Successors, and in the meantime upon trust to let and manage the same as the said Vestrymen shall from Time to Time direct, and to permit them to receive the Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof, if any; and such Rents, Issues, and Profits, if any, shall be applied upon and for the same Trusts, Intents, and Purposes relating to the Endowment of the said Vicarage as are herein-after expressed and declared concerning the Surplus of any Monies to arise from or by the Means herein-after mentioned, except that in case of any Gift of Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments without any valuable Consideration the Rents thereof may (if the Grantors think fit) be reserved to themselves until the said Parish of Richmond shall have become a distinct Vicarage.

XXVII. And be it enacted, That the "Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845," shall be incorporated with and form Part of this Act; and the Clauses and Provisions thereof, so far as they are applicable, shall apply to the Purchase or Acquisition of Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments by the said Vestrymen authorized by this Act, and shall be construed as if the Words "Vestrymen of the Parish of Richmond in the County of Surrey" had been inserted therein, instead of the Words "Promoters of the Undertaking Provided always, that nothing in the said " Lands Clauses Consolidation

XXVIII. Provided also, and be it enacted, That if the said Vestrymen shall enter into any Contract for the Purchase of any Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments of Copyhold or Customary Tenure, they shall, before the Completion or within Three Months after the Completion of such Purchase, enter into an Agreement with the Lord or Lady of the Manor of which the same shall be holden for the Enfranchisement thereof, and shall before the Expiration of Six Months after the Completion of such Purchase enfranchise the same Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments accordingly, if the Lord or Lady of the said Manor consent thereto.

XXIX. And be it enacted, That if after Payment of the Costs, Charges, and Expenses of providing a Residence for the said Vicar of Richmond aforesaid, and of the Conveyance thereof, and of the Deeds relating to the same, or to any Sale or Exchange, as authorized by this Act, there shall be any Surplus of any Monies or Lands or Hereditaments, such Monies shall be laid out and invested in the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or in any of the Public Stocks or Funds of Great Britain, or upon Government or Real Securities in England or Wales, as the Vestrymen for the Time being of the said Parish of Richmond shall think fit; and such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, and Stocks, Funds, or Securities, shall for ever thereafter be an Endowment for the said Vicarage of Richmond, and be held and enjoyed by the Vicar thereof, and his Successors, with the Powers of Sale and Exchange as contained in this Act, subject to any Laws and Regulations for the Time being in force for the Management and Investment of Endowments of Benefices.

XXX. And be it enacted, That the said Vestrymen may from Time to Time appoint a Collector or Collectors of the said Pew Rents, taking from him or them such Security for the due Performance of his or their Duties as they the said Vestrymen shall think fit, and the said Vestrymen shall from Time to Time pay such Salaries and make such reasonable Allowances to him or them as the Case may require (not exceeding in the whole Four Pounds per Centum on the Amount collected by such Collector or Collectors); and the said Vestrymen may from Time to Time remove or displace such Collector or Collectors, or either of them, whenever they shall see Occasion, and appoint another or others in his or their Stead.

XXXI. And be it enacted, That the said Vestrymen may sue and be sued in the Name of the Treasurer of the said Vestrymen for the d ime being, for or concerning any Matter or Thing whatsoever relating to any Matter or Thing whatsoever done or intended to be done by them under the Provisions of this Act; and in any Action of Ejectment brought or prosecuted by the said Vestrymen it shall be sufficient to lay the Demise in the Name of the said Treasurer; and in Proceedings by or on the Part of the said Vestrymen against any

585

12° & 13° VICTORIA,

any Person for stealing or wilfully injuring or otherwise improperly dealing with any Property, Works, or Things belonging to them or under their Management, it shall be sufficient to state generally that the Property or Thing in respect of which the Proceeding is instituted is the Property of the said Treasurer, and all legal Proceedings by or on the Part of the said Vestrymen under or for the Purpose of carrying out the Provisions of this Act may be preferred, instituted, and carried on in his Name; and no Proceedings whatever shall abate or be discontinued by the Death, Resignation, or Removal of any Treasurer, or by reason of any Change or Vacancy in the said Vestrymen by Death, Resignation, or otherwise : Provided always, that no Execution shall issue or be had in any Action or Suit against the said Vestrymen or Treasurer until the Expiration of Six Months after final Judgment has been obtained; and that the Treasurer in whose Name any such Action or Suit, Complaint, Information, or Proceeding, may be brought, preferred, instituted, or defended, as aforesaid, shall be fully reimbursed out of the Pew Rents of the said Parish Church of Richmond aforesaid all such Costs, Charges, Damages, and Expenses as he shall or may be or become liable to pay, sustain, or be put unto by reason of his Name being so used.

XXXII. And be it enacted, That all and every the Powers, Authorities, Enactments, and Provisions contained in the said recited Act of the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His Majesty King George the Third, relating to or concerning the Vestrymen, Churchwardens, Treasurer, and other Officers of the said Parish of Richmond, or any of them, or the Acts, Deeds, Elections, Meetings, and Proceedings of them or any of them, or the Rules and Regulations respecting such Acts, Deeds, Elections, Meetings, and Proceedings, or any of them, shall apply and shall be deemed and construed to apply to the Matters and Things hereby respectively enacted and authorized to be done and carried into effect, as if such Matters and Things were by the said recited Act respectively enacted and authorized to be done and carried into effect, and this Act were incorporated in the said recited

XXXIII. And be it enacted, That no Matter or Thing done or Contract entered into by the said Vestrymen or Churchwardens, nor any Matter or Thing done by any Member of the said Vestry or Churchwardens, or by the Treasurer, Clerk, or other Officer or Person whomsoever, acting under the Direction of the said Vestrymen or Churchwardens, shall, if the Matter or Thing were done or the Contract were entered into bona fide for the Purpose of executing this Act, subject them or any of them personally to any Action, Liability, Claim, or Demand whatsoever; and any Expense incurred by any such Vestryman, Churchwarden, Treasurer, Clerk, or other Officer or Person acting as last aforesaid shall be borne and repaid out of the Pew Rents of the said Church of Richmond aforesaid, or other Monies that may be raised or procured by the said Vestrymen.

XXXIV. And be it enacted, That one Moiety of the Costs, Charges, and Expenses of and attending the applying for and pro-

Treasurer to be reimbursed.

Powers, &c. of 25 G. 3. c. 41. extended to this Act.

Persons acting in the Execution of the Act not to be personally liable.

Saving the Rights of the present Vicar to appoint Curates, and of Inhabitants of Richmond in civil Matters, and of Impropriate Hector.

Interpretation of Terms.

[Public Act.]

12° & 13° VICTORIA, Cup.xlii.

curing and passing this Act, and incidental thereto, shall be borne by the Provost and Scholars of the said College, and shall forthwith be paid by them into the Hands of the Treasurer of the said Parish of Richmond, to be by him applied towards defraying such Costs, Charges, and Expenses, and that One Third Part of the other Moiety of such Costs, Charges, and Expenses shall be paid by the said Vestrymen or their Treasurer out of the Pew Rents of the said Church of Richmond aforesaid, and the remaining Two Third Parts of such Moiety shall be paid by the said Vestrymen or their Treasurer out of the Rents of the Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments vested in the said Vestrymen, or out of any Rents over which they have any Control or Superintendence, in preference to any other Payment whatsoever.

XXXV. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall affect or abridge or be considered to affect or abridge the Rights and Privileges of any Vicar of Kingston upon-Thames and Sheen otherwise Richmond to the Nomination and Appointment of Curates of the Parish of Richmond aforesaid, so long as any such Vicar shall continue to hold the said Parish of Richmond as Part of or in connexion with his said Vicarage of Kingston - it pon- Th a mes and Sheen otherwise Richmond, or affect or abridge the Rights and Privileges of the Vestrymen of the said Parish of Richmond, or of the Inhabitants of the said Parish, so far as relates to all parochial Rights and Privileges, or affect or abridge the Rights of the Impropriate Rector of the said Parish, but all such Rights and Privileges shall remain as before the passing of this Act.

XXXVI. And be it enacted, That in this Act the following Words and Expressions shall have the several Meanings hereby assigned to them, unless there be something in the Subject or Context repugnant to such Construction; (that is to say,)

Words importing the Singular Number shall include the Plural Number, and Words, importing the Plural Number shall include the Singular Number:

Words importing the Masculine Gender only shall include Females:

The Word " Person " shall include Corporation, whether aggregate or sole.

XXXVII. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken as a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others.
